Croatia is banning transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats and transit passengers on March 19.
On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days.

In Croatia on March 19, the government implemented a strict measurement of social distancing to avoid close personal contact at a distance of at least two (2) meters indoors and one (1) meter outdoors for 30 days.

On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers.

On Mar 19 Croatian troops began erecting a tent for a medical camp outside the Dubrava hospital in Zagreb with a capacity of 270 beds to accommodate infected patients and it is expected to be erected by Saturday.

On Mar 21 the Croatia national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by rail, bus and tram, for the next 30 days, and the decision goes into force on Sunday, March 22.
All railway and bus stations will be closed. Travel to islands will be possible only for people who live on islands.
On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior ordered the closure of farm produce markets.

On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23. 
Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.

On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On Mar 27 Croatian coronavirus task force allowed stores that have indoor spaces to reopen, in an effort not to completely strangle economic activity while keeping the coronavirus from spreading rapidly through the population.
On Mar 29 the Croatian government has secured more than 20 tons of protective masks, protective suits and protective goggles from China.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On Mar 30 the Republic of Croatia temporarily closes six permanent border crossings (Umag, Poreč, Rovinj, Mali Lošinj, Korčula and Ubli) and postpones the opening of eleven seasonal crossings (Umag-ACI Marina, Novigrad, Sali, Božava, Primošten, Komiža, Hvar, Vis, Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, Vela Luka and Cavtat) for international passenger traffic in maritime transport.
On Mar 30 the Croatian Police Directorate has called upon all foreigners on short stay in Croatia who are not able to leave Croatia to send their information to the police in order to be registered.

On Mar 31 the Croatian Science Foundation with financing from the Ministry of Science and Education has invited scientists to apply for 14 million kuna in grants for research related to the coronavirus. The research is not limited to medicine and public health, but also the social aspects of the pandemic and its effects on the education system. The researchers have 18 months to complete their projects.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On Mar 31 The Croatian Ministry of the Interior said the border regime would be relaxed allowing Croatian and Hungarian citizens living or working within 30 km of the border to cross the border every day or when necessary. The relaxed sanitary measures refer only to those who have a justified reason to cross the border in order to perform work that is considered economically important as well as to persons who own farms in the other country.

On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 leaving one's place of residence will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On Apr 2 Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have agreed to temporarily close 20 of their mutual border crossings. The traffic is thus suspended at the following border crossings: Svilaj, Gejkovac, Pasin Potok, Bogovolja, Kordunski Ljeskovac, Licka Kaldrma, Bili Brig, Arzano Pazar, Dvorine, Cera, Jovica Most, Sebisina, Slivno, Podprolog, Unka, Vukov Klanac, Imotica, Slano, Hrvatska Dubica and Gabela Polje.
Cuba is strenghtening the public health system with the creation of an task-force to oversee the response to Covid-19 after Jan. 28
Cuba starts the deployment of military hospital to strengthen public health system capacity. Measures are taken by the government but described in public media after Mar. 9
"Cuba's Health Ministry has even posted a video online advising Cubans how to make their own masks." after Mar. 16
Cuba is using the Interferon Alfa-2B to combat the effects of COVID-19 after Mar. 18

In Cuba "isolation for surveillance for 14 days will be applied to all travelers residing in the country in the institutions authorized by the Ministry of Public Health if they presents symptoms.This sanitary measure is of strict compliance after Mar. 20".

Cuba is enforcing that "only cuban resident are allowed to enter the country, with flexibility to ensure cooperation with some countries.Applies for 30 days." Additionally Cuba is "increasing staff capacity.". Half of the restaurants are being closed. Campings, hotels, cinemas and theatres are as well being closed. Implementation of strong social protection to avoid unemployment. All measures taken by the government but described in public media.
"Cuban leader Miguel Díaz-Canel announced Friday night that the country is shutting down most air travel and will not be admitting tourists starting Tuesday." after Mar. 20

"Cuba has reportedly sent 144 health workers to Jamaica, 136 doctors to Venezuela, and 50 doctors to Suriname. In all of these cases, the medical workers will be assisting in the fight against coronavirus."  - Mar.22

In Cuba, "tourists staying in hotels will be confined to those hotels until it is time for them to depart. They cannot leave the hotel unless to go to the aiport. All excursions are suspended. A medic will visit the hotel twice per day. Tourists can only move around for essential trips and in officially authorised and licensed transport, e.g. yellow taxis for trips to the airport to catch their flight. Tourists can no longer rent cars." after Mar.23
Cuba bannes transportation between provinces after Mar. 23

"Cuba’s government said on Monday it was banning Cubans from leaving the country, closing schools and suspending interregional public transport in its fight to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus." - after Mar. 24
Cuba enforces inhabitants to wear masks anytime they leave their house after Mar. 26.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
In Cuba "The Pinar del Río government decreed quarantine for the El Canal People’s Council, in the municipality of Consolación del Sur, after learning of a new case of local transmission of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19. This is the first community in Cuba that is isolated due to the epidemic." after Apr. 1
UPDATE:  "Violating the sanitary provisions established in the middle of the epidemic of coronavirus, which causes COVID-19, constitutes a crime according to Chapter 5 of the current Penal Code" after Mar. 31
Cuba "announced the temporary suspension of the shipment of cargo and parcels sent by people on a commercial basis." after Mar. 28

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Cuba has yet sent another medical brigade to help fight CoVid-19. This time they are supporting Saint Kitts and Nevis after Mar. 29
target_country: Saint Kitts and Nevis,Saint Kitts and Nevis,Saint Kitts and Nevis

event_description: Cuba startet social distancuing by making "people keeping a sensible distance away from each other, limiting movement in public spaces" after Mar. 30
Cuba "announced the suspension of all commercial and charter flights to the island starting Apr. 2, prohibiting also all foreign sea traffic in Cuban waters."

"Cuba’s government has suspended its May Day Parade, a fixture of the country’s calendar since the 1959 revolution, due to fears that it could promote the spread of the novel coronavirus, reports dpa news." - Apr. 1
Cuba is ready to help in Nigeria’s COVID-19 battle after Apr. 1

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: "Cuba has dispatched 593 medical workers to 14 countries in their battles against the pandemic, its ministry of public health told Al Jazeera." after Apr. 1

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: "The Cuban government has agreed to assist Ghana with a medical brigade made up of specialist doctors, nurses and medicines to fight the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) if Ghana makes a formal request in that direction." after Apr.1
Cuba suspends all flights, except humanitarian, from April 2

In Cyprus, on 28 February 2020, the Council of Ministers decided to activate the Cyprus Crisis Management Centre, to suspend the operation of 4 crossing points for more effective control of those passing though and to identify government accommodation facilities or camp sites for the isolation of suspected cases in the event of a pandemic.

Cyprus announced that from 1 a.m. of 15 March and for a period of 15 days in the first phase, the prohibition of entry to any citizen - regardless of nationality - who does not fall into the following categories: Cypriot citizens, Legal residents in the Republic of Cyprus, European nationals or third-country nationals working in the Republic under bilateral or international conventions, Nationals of countries who are in a designated diplomatic service or mission, Individual cases of European nationals or third-country nationals for unavoidable professional obligations, provided that the relevant authorization has been obtained from the competent Ministry, European or third country citizens attending educational institutions in the Republic of Cyprus. As regards the crossing points between the free and the occupied areas, entry will be permitted only to persons falling into the following categories: Cypriot citizens, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, Legal residents in the free areas, Nationals of countries who are in a designated diplomatic service or mission under bilateral or international conventions.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
In Cyprus, the operation of public and private schools is suspended until the 10th of April 2020.
During the suspension of the operation of public schools, the Minister of Education and Culture has been authorized to implement alternative methods, via technology, to respond to educational needs and cover a part of the educational programme, for as long as schools will be closed.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Entry into the Republic of Cyprus of those persons mentioned in the previous address, will only be granted to those who, upon their arrival, submit a medical certificate that they have been tested for coronavirus by certified medical centers from their country of origin. Those who fulfil these conditions will be placed under a 14-day compulsory quarantine at accommodation facilities designated by the Republic of Cyprus. Students who opt to stay in their places of study, will be granted a 750 allowance. Our decision shall also apply to those who use the crossing points between the free and the occupied areas, except for purely humanitarian reasons and following approval by the Minister of Interior.

Cyprus - Work on construction sites where more than three people are working simultaneously, shall be suspended as of 6am of 31 March until 6 am of 13 April 2020. This restriction does not apply to public utility projects and requests that concern urgent construction work relating to safety concerns and hazardous situations.

Cyprus - The public service and the wider public sector as well as persons working in the education service, for the upcoming month, as of 17/03/2020, will work as follows:
• where possible from their own homes,
• with security personnel for urgent matters and serving the public for emergency cases.
Hotels (in Cyprus) will suspend operations until 30 April 2020. To serve existing customers, they may continue their operation for a period of six days from today (15 March).

In accordance to a decision taken by the Council of Ministers on 15 March 2020, as of 16 March 2020, on 6 am, for a duration of four weeks, the closure of the following businesses is mandatory:
• Shopping Malls and Department Stores,
• Cafes, restaurants, bars and all catering companies with the exception of those that offer home delivery services,
• Night clubs,
   
• Cinemas and theatres,
• Libraries,
• Museums, archaeological and historical sites,
• Gambling agencies, casinos, etc.,
• Sports facilities, sports clubs, cultural groups and associations,
• Theme parks (amusement parks, etc.),
• Barber shops, hairdressers, beauty-massage centres.

As long as these businesses observe strict hygiene rules, they may carry out administrative and other operations behind closed doors. 

For reasons of health safety and health of the community, the following categories of
enterprises remain open (see Decree by the Minister of Health https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/en/diat.html)
• Food retailing (e.g. supermarkets* must ensure there are no more than one person per 8 m2);
• Pharmacies
• Private health services (clinical laboratories),
• Bakeries and confectioneries (no table seats),
• Gas stations, and
• Convenience stores.
Cyprus: It has been decided, initially, to allocate of the amount of 100 million euros for reinforcing the public health sector.

the Government has decided to adopt a comprehensive exceptional financial Support Programme for the working people, the small and medium-sized enterprises and in general of all Cypriot businesses. The “Support Programme” that has been formulated is structured and specific, both in range as well as in expenditure, and it is valued at 700 million euros, an amount equal to the 3% of the GDP.

Cyprus: the Ministry of Labour, Welfare and Social Insurance announces that, as of Monday, 23 March, the pancyprian 1433 call center will begin operation, to respond to questions of the public on measures concerning the Ministry of Labour, Welfare and Social Insurance only. The call center will operate from Monday to Friday from 08:00 to 18:00. The call center’s operating hours during weekends will be announced shortly.
Cyprus: Suspension of non-emergent cases and surgeries, ban on patient visitors

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Cyprus government suspends flights and closes hotels from March 21 due to coronavirus (COVID-19); confirm travel itineraries

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Cyprus: the Minister of Health has issued a new Decree that came into force on March 21st 2020, setting special hours at supermarkets. In specific, supermarkets from the time of their opening until 10 a.m. will exclusively cater only people who (a) belong to the vulnerable groups, (b) are over 60 years old and (c) those with disabilities.

Cyprus: "Ban on unnecessary movement from 6.00PM March 24 until April 13, except: transfer to/from workplace, Transfer for the purposes of supplies of basic necessities from businesses or shops whose operation is allowed and given that shipping is not possible, Visit to doctor or transit to a pharmacy, Visit to a bank if electronic transactions are not possible, Transit with the purpose to aid fellow citizens who cannot look after themselves or to groups of people who must be protected, or who are in self-isolation and/or in premises of compulsory isolation (quarantine), First and second degree relatives going to ceremonies, such as funerals, weddings and christenings, not exceeding ten people, Transit for physical exercise or for the needs of a pet, provided they are not more than two people and they remain limited in areas adjacent to their residence.
Under all circumstances, all persons moving about must carry identification and additional proof as to the purpose of their movement. Further details and the way of control will be announced tomorrow. In addition to any other criminal liability to offenders, an extrajudicial penalty of EUR 150 will be imposed."

Cyprus: "as of 6 p.m. of the 24th of March 2020 until the 13th of April 2020, the following places will also be closed:
i. Parks.
ii. Playgrounds.
iii. Open-air sport spaces.
iv. Public gathering areas, among others, squares, dams, excursion sites, beaches, marinas.
3. All retailers shall suspend their operations, except from the businesses that will be included in a relevant Decree that will be issued within the day by the Minister of Health.
4. Open markets, bazaars and itinerant sales are prohibited.
5. Work on construction sites shall be terminated, except construction works relating to public utility projects and subject to
the relevant permission from the Minister of Transport, Communications and Works.
6. It is prohibited for citizens to attend places of religious worship, such as churches, mosques and other places for prayer.
7. Prohibition of the custom of ""lighting a bonfire"" with immediate removal of timber or other materials already assembled for this purpose. The responsibility for implementing this ban lies with the local authorities in cooperation with the police. In addition to any other criminal liability to offenders, an extrajudicial penalty of EUR 150 will be imposed."

Cyprus: the UK National Federation of Cypriots is launching a program, under the auspices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to send a free package of basic foodstuffs, containing mainly Cypriot products, to students in the UK

Cyprus: Suspension of payment of the VAT in the framework of the support programme to address the effects of the virus COVID-19: Under the Value Added Tax (Amending) Law of 2020 (L.24(I)/2020), the right of suspension of the obligation of payment of the VAT is conferred to the persons registered in the VAT Registry, whose specified taxation periods end on the 29th of February 2020, the 31st of March 2020 and the 30th of April 2020.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
The right of entry into the Republic of Cyprus without the presentation of a medical examination certificate for coronavirus applies to:
Those who have travelled abroad for medical reasons, as well as the persons who accompanied them at their departure or hospitalization.
Students who belong to "vulnerable groups" in relation to the coronavirus, in accordance with the Press release issued by the Ministry of Health, dated 16 March 2020.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
Cyprus: "as from 31st March 2020 at 6 a.m.:
1. Gatherings of people at any residence are prohibited, other than of permanent residents.
2. Any movement of persons from 9.00 p.m. until 6.00 a.m. is prohibited, except for those
holding a Confirmation of Movement of an Employee certificate (Form A).
3. The use of the certificate of a citizen’s movement in exceptional cases, in accordance with
the provisions of Form B, is limited to only once a day, after permission has been obtained by sending an SMS message to 8998. A written declaration for the movement of citizens in exceptional cases, which falls within the provisions of Form B, shall be used only by persons over 65 years of age."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
Cyprus: "The following retailers will remain closed every Sunday:
1. All food and beverage retailers (e.g. supermarkets, grocery stores, butchers, fish markets, bakeries, confectioneries, fruit shops, liquor stores).
It is understood that kiosks are excluded from the ban, provided that they do not market retail products.
As from tomorrow Tuesday at 6 a.m. the operation of the following services is also suspended:
1. Tourist and travel agencies.
2. Aircraft provision services, with the exception of those relating to the service of flights
which are exceptionally approved by the Minister of Transport, Communications and
Works as well as cargo flights.
3. The number of persons including the driver during taxi rides, in a private cars and/or in
other vehicles shall not exceed three persons.
Businesses must provide all necessary signs to ensure that there is a two metres distance between citizens both inside and outside the business (i.e. within the shops/businesses and in the queues outside the shops/businesses).
In addition, when approaching a public-accessible area, citizens should ensure that they keep a distance of 2 metres from other fellow citizens.
In addition to the decree and what I have just said, the following measures have been decided by the interministerial committee:
1. Increase in the fine from 150 euros to 300 euros.
2. Increase of controls at check points.
3. Utilization of neighborhood watch officers.
4. Recommendations will be made to commercial banks to issue credit cards to beneficiaries
based on their deposits and ways of protecting customers who withdraw cash from
automatic cash points.
5. In order to limit the movement of those who have been identified as positive to the
coronavirus and are in self-isolation, the Ministry of Health is studying ways to impose electronic home surveillance."

Cyprus: the Council of Ministers approved a bill by the Ministry of Justice and Public Order, which amends the amount of extrajudicial penalty that may be imposed on persons in violation of decrees of the Minister of Health, under the Law on Vaccination, raising the fine to 300 Euros from 150 Euros. it remains possible, if it is considered appropriate by law enforcement officers, not to impose an extrajudicial fine and to choose for a criminal case to be filed in court, which may impose prison sentences of up to six months and / or a fine much greater than the extrajudicial fine, which can be up to 3,000 Euros. This procedure will be selected in the most serious cases.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

event_description:
Cyprus: "The Deputy Ministry of Research, Innovation and Digital Policy announces the following modifications with regard to the procedure for obtaining an approval for movement by way of exception for serving needs which cannot be covered in alternative ways. Procedure for an Approval of Movement of citizens by way of exception:
• For all movements by way of exception, each confirmation of movement refers to just one particular movement.
• Each citizen is allowed movement by way of exception only once a day.
• With regard to the procedure of requesting approval for movement by way of exception:
1. Persons under the age of 65 can request approval only by sending a text message (SMS) to 8998, written in the correct format.
2. Persons over the age of 65 (and only them) have three (3) options to request approval for movement by way of exception:
• • By sending an SMS to the number 8998.
• By filling out and printing Form B.
• By carrying a hand-written Citizens' Solemn Declaration.
• During each movement, citizens must have with them, in order to show it in the event of a check, the filled-out form for the confirmation of movement (print out or handwritten) or the confirmation SMS that they have received, as well as identification proof as follows:
1. Cyprus citizens: Cyprus ID card
2. European citizens and third country nationals: registration confirmation or residence permit respectively. For those who justifiably do not have the above documents a registration, then, by way of exception, another identification document will be accepted, e.g. international passport, international ID card, diplomatic passport.
• It is stressed that, according to the provisions of the decree dated 30/03/2020, any movement of persons from 9.00 p.m. until 6.00 a.m. is prohibited, except for those citizens holding a Confirmation of Movement of Employee (Form A) and provided that the form allows them to be moving within that timeframe."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The Minister of Communications and Works, Mr Yiannis Karousos, issued today, 4 April 2020, a Decree concerning the prohibition of flights as of 12.00 am Cyprus time, April 4, 2020 and for a 14 -day period, except for those related to the transport of cargo, departure of passengers from the Republic of Cyprus and flights for humanitarian purposes.

Czech Republic Ministry of Health implements a protective measure targeted specifically at the Prague International Airport and its employees. It includes a verbal announcement about what to do should travelers develop COVID-19 symptoms in every plane landing in Prague, gathered in an information leaflet.
Czech Republic bans all international airlines from operating direct flights from China to Czech Republic.
Czech Republic's Security Council discourages from traveling to the Italian regions of Veneto and Lombardy.
Czech Republic's Ministry of Health temporarily banned direct flight connection from South Korea as well as from all airports in the Italian regions of Emilia-Romagna, Piemont, Lombardy and Veneto.

Czech Ministry of Health decides that the planned BMW IBU World Cup Biathlon as planned between March 5 and March 8 2020 (annual sports event with thousands of attendees) will go on without an audience.
Czech Ministry of Health bans the export and sale of type FFP3 respirator masks to organisations or individuals outside the medical or law enforcement sectors.
Czech Government ruled that all events over 5000 participants need to report to their local hygienic station.
Czech Ministry of Health bans all persons - aside from manufacturers - from exporting hand sanitizer products.

Czech Ministry of Health mandates all persons residing in Czech Republic returning from Italy after March 7, 2020 to report to their general practitioner doctor. Doctors are then required to put these individuals into a 14-day quarantine.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Czech Republic Ministry of Health implements an exception to the mandatory quarantine measures from March 6, 2020, relevant to freight transportation employees, medical ambulance crews and commercial pilots. If observing symptoms of COVID-19, such individuals are to report to their general practitioner. They are mandated to use increased hygiene measures during their work (including respirators type FFP2 or FFP3).

Czech Ministry of Health cancels public visiting hours in hospitals, social services provider centers and retirement homes. Exception applies in the case of underage patients, patients who require legal guardianship, pregnant women and patients in final stages of a terminal illness.
Czech government implements "akce Korona" - an operation where law enforcement carries out temperature checks on border crossings.
Czech Ministry of Health bans the physical presence of students in primary, secondary and grammar and vocational schools as well as in universities.
Czech Government bans cultural, educational and sports events with over 100 participants. Court proceedings, governmental meetings and board meetings are exempted.
Government of the Czech Republic announces a state of emergency. By default, this lasts 30 days (without consent of the Parliament needed).
Czech Government bans Czech citizens and foreign citizens with permanent residence in Czech Republic from leaving the Czech Republic.

Czech Government bans all foreign nationals from entering the country, with the exception of individuals with long-term residence in Czech Republic and individuals whose entry is in the interest of the state.

Czech Government imposes mandatory home quarantine on individuals traveling from (or recently residing in) risk countries, which were specified as: China, South Korea, Iran, Italy, Spain, Austria, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Netherlands, Belgium, Great Britain, Norway, Denmark and France.
Czech Government closes all non-essential businesses and restaurants, with the exception of catering facilities used exclusively by business employees. Only take-away services are permitted.

Czech Government restricts free movement to all unnecessary travel. People are permitted to leave their houses to travel to work, to purchase groceries or medication, visit family or exercise / get fresh air.

Czech Government encourages citizens over 70 years of age to isolate at home, only leaving to obtain necessary medical care. Mayors and local governments are asked to assist senior citizens with securing groceries and other necessities.

Czech Government plans to re-orient two hospitals exclusively on care for COVID-19 patients. Specifically, this should be Nemocnice na Homolce in Prague and Fakultní nemocnice u sv. Anny in Brno, each with the capacity of around 300 hospital beds.
On March 17, Czech Government issues a ban on re-export of medical supplies and medicines which were originally meant for Czech markets.

Czech Government manned law enforcement workers from pursuing an additional income outside of their employment in law enforcement. This policy is to last as long as the national state of emergency is in place.

Czech Government prevents all residents from appearing in public (outside of their homes) without a physical cover of their mouth and nose. Respirators, face masks, home-made masks as well as scarves are admissible.

On March 18 the Czech Government issued a policy addressing cross-border workers, ordering them to limit their movement within Czech Republic. This policy also cancelled some of the exceptions from free movement restriction (policy from March 15). Cross-border workers will be subjected to temperature checks while crossing the border and a COVID-19 test will be administered to them if they show symptoms of the illness.

Czech Government dedicates special hours in grocery stores specifically for individuals of 65+ years of age; anyone younger who is not a legal guardian of an elderly customer nor employee of the store cannot enter the store facilities between 10am and 11am.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Czech Government reserves the time between 7am and 9am for grocery stores to only be visited by citizens over 65 years of age (and their guardians, if needed).

On March 24 (effective at 6am), Czech Government restricts free movement of residents in groups bigger than two individuals. Exception applies to families, work or business activities and funerals.

Citizens are advised to keep a distance of 2 meters from each other at all times.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Czech Government changes the time reserved for seniors over 65 years of age to visit grocery stores to 8am - 10am. This applies specifically to stores over 500 meters square in size of facility.

Czech Government mandates shops which sell baked goods which are not prepackaged to maintain special hygiene measures. Shops are to ensure that people are able to maintain 2m distance, preventing overcrowding.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Czech Republic Ministry of Education extends protective measures to apply to 4 more international airports, namely airports in Ostrava, Karlovy Vary, Brno and Pardubice. Same measures apply.

The Democratic Republic of Congo introduces of quarantine policies: 14 day quarantine for high risk countries including mainland China, South Korea, Iran, Italy. Also for travelers with COVID-19 symptoms starting March 4.

The Democratic Republic of the Congo is enforcing a 14-day self-quarantine on passengers having traveled to China, France, Germany, Italy, Iran, South Korea, and Iraq in the 14 days prior to their arrival into the country but who show no symptoms at their time of arrival. Passengers who transited in the countries but did not leave the airport are subject to no restrictions.

Democratic Republic of the Congo implements health checks at the airports for all passengers starting on March 10. Those who show symptoms will be moved to government facilities for further testing, and those who test positive for Covid-19 will be hospitalized at government expense.
DRC closes schools and universities on March 18.
DRC bans gatherings of more than 20 people on March 18.

event_description: All travelers entering the DRC who have a fever will be tested, and any persons positive for COVID-19 will be hospitalized at DRC government expense. Both categories will be subject to a mandatory 14-day quarantine.  All persons traveling domestically from Kinshasa to other provinces will be subject to preventative screening.
As of March 21, 2020 The Republic of Congo closed its borders and all international passenger flights are suspended

event_description: The Democratic Republic of the Congo has declared a national state of heath emergency on March 25th.
DRC closes all international borders on March 25.
DRC bans travel between Kinshasa and all other regions in the country.
DR Congo implements three-week confinement in Kinshasa starting 28 March.

event_description: The 3-week confinement in Kinshasa set to begin on March 28 has been reported to a later date.
Democratic Republic of Congo institutes a 20-day home confinement and a curfew from 20:00 until 05:00 are implemented as of April 1, 2020.

event_description: Denmark is enforcing a Health Resources Measure: Widening Test capacity in all hospitals after Feb 25.
Denmark is enforcing a Quarantine on all positive-tested covid19-cases and their close contacts after Feb 28.

Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. Anybody that has been in close contact with someone who is known to be infected by SARS-CoV-2 is placed in home quarantine as well. Quarantine in those cases is enforced for 14 days. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020.
Denmark is enforcing a new health resources measure: no one should wear a face mask (with/without symptoms, risk group or not) after March 3.
Denmark is enforcing a voluntary Quarantine on all travelers from risk areas who returned to denmark after March 2.

The public sector and private companies must send home, without exception, to
following workers:
● Over 60 years,
● Pregnant women,
● People with chronic diseases, such as kidney failure,
immunosuppressed, serious heart conditions and all cases that
indicate the Ministry of Labor.

The outpatient consultation of the 31 national hospitals and all health units
 are suspended until further notice.

The agglomerations of more than 50 people are prohibited, except
workplaces, people in circulation and bus terminals.

Duicenters, bars, clubs and gyms must be closed for at least 14 days,
from the moment it was decreed.

The public sector should send workers who are not
strictly necessary to provide vital services, without exception. This measure includes all the other organs of the State and all the mayoralties.

It is recommended to companies that are not food, medicine or
supplies necessary for the operation of the country, to send the staff to
home, for a fee. The Government will benefit all companies that thus
they do so, prequalifying them with productive and working capital credits for part of the Mortgage Bank.

The Consumer Protection Office will initiate pricing to prevent abuse
and hoarding will be fined.

The Vice Ministry of Transport and the Ministry of Public Works will verify that public transport drivers wear face masks and put alcohol gel on
Passenger disposal, in addition to sanitizing the units 3 times a day.
Construction of a  hospital has begun to attend the pandemic. It will have 300 Care Units Intensive and more than 2,000 hospital beds, exclusive for confirmed patients.
Closure of El Salvador Airport

Service is suspended at tables in all restaurants, cafes, dining rooms,
 from 6 p.m. of this day (03/18). The operation will be allowed
of these businesses under the modalities to take, to domiciles and windows of self-service. This measure is taken after a thorough analysis to prevent the contagion and at the same time guarantee -as far as possible- the subsistence of people who live on these jobs and small businesses.

El Salvador Government has determined that all households consuming below 250 kilowatt-hours of energy per month, will receive a transfer of US $ 300 the purchase of basic food and supplies, in order to survive the quarantine. This benefit is for people who do not have an employment relationship, no permanent income and that they are economically affected by the pandemic. 
Likewise, public employees who carry out activities directly to combat COVID-19,  (such as Ministry of Health employees) will be compensated with US $ 150.
The President of the Republic, Nayib Bukele, decreed Mandatory Household Quarantine for all Salvadorans for the next 30 days, to prevent the advance of the pandemic COVID-19.

All international flights in Equatorial Guinea were cancelled starting March 15th. Travellers from countries affected have to follow a 14-day quarantine. Domestic flights were cancelled in the following days.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea urges all nationals and foreigners who may have plans to travel to, and from Eritrea, to postpone their plans.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announced on the 11th March 2020 that all visitors who originate directly from, or who have transited through, China, Italy, South Korea and Iran will be quarantined.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that continuous sensitization campaigns will be disseminated through the various local media outlets in order to provide timely and full information to the general public. These announcements must be followed with due diligence.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that every person should refrain from internal as well as foreign travel unless this is for extremely urgent and unavoidable purposes from the 16th March 2020 onwards.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea urges every person to avoid, in as much as this is possible, public gatherings from the 16th March 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that every person should avoid non-essential movement within the city or village of residence as well as travel to other places inside the country. Every person should likewise avoid travel by bus, mini-bus and taxis unless in emergencies from the 23rd March 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces, that all public gatherings, sport and cultural events that assemble a crowd of more than 10 people are prohibited. Cinemas and night-clubs will remain closed until further notice from the 23rd March 2020 onwards.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces to all citizens and foreigners residing in the country that social distancing must be heeded to in other commercial units and centers.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that aggregation of more than 10 people at social events (funerals, weddings, mourning, baptism and other gatherings) is banned. Every citizen must observe, and same instruction is being given by religious leaders to the faithful, prayers and associated religious sermons in their homes from the 23rd March 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that stringent legal measures will be taken on all individuals and commercial enterprises that engage in hoarding and speculative price hikes by misconstruing the precautionary measures that are being taken to safeguard the safety of the Eritrean people and the country from the 23rd March 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all commercial passenger flights to and from Eritrea will not be allowed from midnight today, (25 March 2020). The ban will remain effective for two weeks until further review.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all institutions of learning - from Kindergarten to Colleges - will be closed starting from 27th March 2020, issued on 26th March 2020.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all public transport vehicles - buses, minibuses and taxis – in all the cities will stop services from 6:00 a.m. tomorrow, March 27th.  Use of trucks for public transport is illicit and punishable by law. With the exception of those who may be granted special permit by the competent authority in urgent circumstances, all public transport services from one Region to another, or from one city to another, will likewise be stopped from 6:00 a.m. tomorrow, 27 March 2020.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that bars, restaurants, cafés and other service outlets that cater to sizeable clients will be closed for 14 days from 6:00 a.m. tomorrow, 31st March 2020. All employees of these enterprises will not be laid off and their full salary for  the period in question will be borne by the employer.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that payment of electricity, water and telephone household bills will be postponed from 30th March 2020 onwards.
The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all court sessions – at all levels – will be postponed until further notice, from 30th March 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that members of a household, not exceeding two at a time, are allowed to go out from their homes to buy essential food items during the day. This conditional permission also holds for emergency medical treatment. With the exception of citizens employed in institutions that will continue their functions, all other individuals confined to their homes are not allowed to use their private cars during this period.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all trading activities and transactions will be banned in this period (21 days). Similarly, weekly markets that occur in various parts of the country will remain closed.  Food production, supply and processing enterprises as well as grocery stores, pharmacies and banks will however continue to provide services. These institutions will close at 8:00 pm every evening. Major productive and service sectors (manufacturing, food processing, construction, Trucking etc.) will continue their functions. Citizens in the rural areas engaged in farming and animal husbandry will continue to engage in their vital developmental tasks. All personnel of the public and private bodies that will continue their operations will be issued with permits by their respective institutions, from 2nd April 2020 onwards.

The Ministry of Health of Eritrea announces that all Government Institutions will stop routine services and functions to focus on indispensable developmental and security tasks. Majority of public sector employees will thus stay at home. All personnel of the public and private bodies that will continue their operations will be issued with permits by their respective institutions from the 2nd April 2020 onwards.

People will also need to start filling in forms upon entering the country in order to identify the origin of their stay. Sanitary inspections will also be employed in airports and ports. The requirement to fill in forms will be introduced similarly to the land border crossing points."

Following the declaration of emergency in Estonia, the Estonian Government decided that "Museums and cinemas will be closed to visitors until 1 May. All performances, concerts, and conferences are prohibited." after March 12.

Estonian Government declared that as of 12 March, "Estonian residents and foreign citizens arriving from these countries must remain in quarantine for two weeks. The countries are: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, certain departments of France, the federal states of Germany, the state of Tyrol in Austria, Japan, Singapore, and Spain (Madrid, Catalonia, and the Basque Country)."

"President David W. Panuelo of Micronesia (FSM) declared a State of Public Health Emergency" that applies to all citizens in order "to protect the Nation and its citizens from the new coronavirus".

"All citizens of Micronesia are banned from travelling to mainland China and other countries with confirmed cases of Coronavirus until further notice and until such a time that a determination is made that the Coronavirus is effectively maintained. Other citizens, nationals, and residents in FSM are strongly advised against taking unnecessary travel to mainland China and other countries, states, and territory with confirmed cases of Coronavirus until the situation is reassessed and found to be under control"
"Persons travelling directly or indirectly, either by air or sea transport, from anywhere in mainland China since January 6, 2020, are banned from entering into the FSM."

Persons travelling into the FSM from countries , states, or territories with confirmed cases of the Coronavirus (other than mainland China) are not allowed to enter the FSM unless they have stayed in a country, state, or territory with no confirmed cases of Coronavirus for a period not less than 14 days immediately prior to their entry into FSM.

On 16 March 2020, the Finnish Government announced that there is a state of emergency in the country as a result of the coronavirus outbreak. On March 31, the exercise of powers under the Emergency Powers Act is extended until 13 May 2020.

On March 16, the Finnish Government's Ministry of education and culture has adopted policy recommendations for the education sector. "Early childhood education and care units and the pre-primary education associated will be kept in operation. However, the Government recommends children being cared for at home."For primary and lower secondary education, school premises will be closed until 13 April 2020 and contact teaching will be suspended. As an exception, pre-primary education organised in schools and contact teaching for pupils in grades 1 to 3 will continue for the children of parents who work in sectors critical to the functioning of society. The premises of schools, educational institutions, universities, universities of applied sciences, basic art education as well as civic education and other liberal education institutes will be closed until 13 April 2020, and contact teaching will be suspended. Teaching and guidance will be organised as widely as possible in alternative ways, including distance learning. All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customer and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations’ meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed until 13 April. These arrangements were entered into force on Wednesday 18 March 2020. On March 31, the exceptional arrangements for education were announced to be extended until 13 May, and considering the situations of the pandemic, possibly to the end of the term.

Updated on March 30, 2020, Ministry for foreign affairs of Finland is recommending Finish citizens to "avoid travel abroad until further notice. This applies to travel to all countries and to both road, sea and air transport. Foreigners travelling in Finland can leave the country." All Finnish citizens and permanent residents who are returning to Finland from another country are required to remain in conditions equivalent to quarantine for 14 days

On 27 March, the Finnish Government put the restrictions concerning movement to and from the Uusimaa region in practice. The movement restrictions in the Uusimaa region will enter into force on 28 March and remain in force until 19 April 2020. The residents of Uusimaa must stay in the Uusimaa region. Residents of other regions are not allowed to visit Uusimaa.

On 31 March, the Finnish Government issued a decree restricting the operations of restaurants throughout the country. All restaurants must be closed starting from Saturday 4 April 2020. The restrictions will remain in force until the end of May. The restrictions apply to all restaurant operations except for preparing food for take away and for delivery by food couriers. The restrictions do not apply to canteens or restaurants that are essential for food supply such as canteens in schools, hospitals and similar establishments, or personnel restaurants that serve in-house personnel only.

Starting January 28th, 2020 the german national government requires pilots on planes arriving from china to inform the Tower about the health conditions of their passengers. Passengers on those flights are als asked to fill out questionaires about their health conditions. Airlines have to provide seating plans for each flight from China to track potential spreads.

Reporting obligation under the infectious disease protection law for medical personnel in case a patient is suspected to be infected with or deceased to "2019-nCoV". The obligation exists under the occurence of symptoms on the patient as put together by the Robert-Koch Institute (§ 4 Absatz 2 Nummer 1 of the infectious disease law).

Reporting obligation for medical personnel in cases they encounter a patient who is infected with or has deceased to "2019-nCoV" starting Feb 1st, 2020. This is under the "infectious disease protection law" and applicable on recognition of symptoms as defined by the Robert-Koch Institute (see § 4 Absatz 2 Nummer 1 of the Infectious Disease Protection Law).

Quaranting of persons part of the return program out of Hubei province in China for the duration of 14 days. Condition for the transfer was being free of symptoms. The transfer took place on Feb 1s 2020.

On 16th, March 2020, the german ministry of internal affairs announced the closure of non-essential businesse, namely clubs, bars, museum, operas, concert halls, swimming pool, fitness centers, etc. Restrictions also apply to non-essential retail stores. Restaurants have to beclosed after 6pm and hotels can only offer rooms for non-touristic purposes. Additionally, visits to nursing homes and hospitals are to be reduced.

On February 27th, 2020 measures for public information of the german population were implemented. Additionally to available information on websites of three different government agencies, this includes daily information sessions with the Robert-Koch Institute are announced. Furthermore, existing health-related public callcenters were equipped with additional staff to answer information calls.

On February 28th, 2020 the constitution of a task force to deal with the spread of the Corona Virus in Germany. It consists of of members of the federal ministries of public health, internal affairs, foreign affairs and the federal police. Selected input of expertise from other government agencies will also be sought after.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 28th, 2020 measures to provide informations about personal health conditions were expanded. Passengers entering the country by train or coach are from any country are also asked to voluntarily fill out a contact record formula
Starting March 4th, 2020 the export of medical protection gear (e.g. gloves, mask, protection suits, etc.) is prohibited.

Starting March 4th, 2020 pharmacies are allowed to produce desinfection agents after the formula provided by the federal agency. This applies both to personal usecases and to the increased demand from the population.

On March 4th, 2020 the German ministry for Health annouced that it will engage in the purchase of various medical equipment to supply hospitals and other medical facilities who experience shortages in the future.

On March 10th, 2020 the Task Force on Coronavirus responses recommended the cancellation of events with more than 1000 participants. For all other events, risk evaluation as recommended by the Robert-Koch Institute should be conducted.
On March 10th, 2020 the german federal government announced stricter entry controls on the borders of Southern Germany.
On March 10, 2020 the german ministry of foreign affairs discourages traveling to Italy.
On March 11th, 2020 the german ministry for research and education announced the provision of 145 million € for research purposes on the coronavirus.
Starting March 16th, 2020 hospitals in Germany are asked to postpone non-essential surgeries.
On March 14th, 2020 the government prompted travelers returning from Italy, Switzerland and Austria to sty in self-isolation for at least 14 days.

On March 15th, 2020 the german government announced that starting the next days it will enforce restrictions on country entries and exits at its borders. German citizens can enter at all times, but exits are only permitted under reasonable purpose (e.g. work), the same applies to entries of foreign nationals. Traffic in goods will not be touched by this regulation.

On March 17th, 2020 the german ministry of foreign affairs has initiated a returners program for german citizens in other countries who want to return. Countries that will be covered include Marocco, Egypt, The Dominican Republic, the Phillipines and the Maledives.

All social contacts are to be minimized to the absolute and distance of 1.5m is to be kept at all times. This applies for the next 2 weeks at least.

On March 23th, 2020 the German federal government released a law the offers support and incentives to hospitals, doctors, care centers and health insurers to ease financial strain during the crisis and provide more necessary resources (e.g. intensive care beds, etc.)

On March 27th, 2020 the national government of Germany issued a law proclaiming the coronavirus as an "Epidemic situation on a national scale". This provides the government with the ability to take a wide range of measures (e.g. health screenings on borders, provision of medical supplies, etc.) as well as other abilities to gain access to relevant data from private organization (e.g. airlines) if the don't comply with prevous regulations.

Grenada: Prime Minister "has assured healthcare workers that the necessary resources will be made available as Grenada’s intensifies its preparedness activities in light of the threat posed by the Coronavirus, COVID-19."

Grenada: "This means that the island is on what is referred to as Importation Transmission Watch (ITW). These include assessing exposure to risks, monitoring events in the region, and providing pretravel training."

Grenada: "The MOH advises people who develop a fever, cough or shortness of breath within 14 days of visiting the above listed countries, to contact their family doctor and the Health authorities on 440-2649 during regular working hours (i.e., 8:00am–4:00pm), 417-1079, or 417-2562 after regular working hours, weekends and holidays.

These travelers are advised to refrain from visiting health centers or the casualty department in the first instance."

Grenada: "The Ministry of Education will work in collaboration with the Ministry of Health to ensure that teachers and students are equipped with basic information about preventing the spread of the virus by practicing proper cough, sneeze and handwashing techniques. Grenada: "All schools in Grenada, Carriacou and Petite Martinique will be closed for two (2) weeks for the first instance, as of Monday, March 16, 2020, as a necessary precaution against the contracting or spreading of COVID-19.
Teachers are being asked to work from home as of Wednesday, March 18, 2020. Educators and administrators are asked to report to schools on March 16 and 17 to prepare all relevant materials needed to work remotely. "

Grenada: "The Supervisor of Elections wishes to inform the general public that due to the present threat posed by the Corona Virus (COVID-19), all constituency offices will be closed until further notice from Monday, March 16, 2020."

Guatemala announces 1) reinforced epidemiological vigilance, 2) that it created a kiosk in the international airport La Aurora to evaluate "any unusual respiratory health event"

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
Guatemala's Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance of the Republic of Guatemala (MSPAS) announces that travellers from Wuhan, China, with respiratory symptoms are being monitored (at the kiosk?). 
All patients in the country with severe respiratory infections are under observation. 
Mechanisms of "internal coordination" between the MSPAS and other agencies have been "activated."

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: January 22nd, Guatemala recommends that all citizens heading to China and other countries with reported cases follow the recommended actions to prevent respiratory diseases.

Guatemala screens inbound travellers from countries with reported cases at random and has started checking people for "suspicious symptoms" at border points, airport and ports. All cargo, luggage, and imports coming from countries with reported cases are being thoroughly checked. Fumigation is used in some cases to disinfect new cargo.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 24th, Guatemala continues to maintain its recommendation to travellers headed to China and other countries with reported cases to follow prevention guidelines. following its original announcement on January 22nd

On January 27th, Guatemala condemns the spread of fake news online claiming that the first coronavirus case was confirmed in the country, reasserts that there is no such case, and asks all residents to beware of such misinformation and to obtain news from official government sources.

In Guatemala, as part of the preventive measures implemented, an isolated area was set up in the Japan-Guatemala Friendship Hospital to treat future coronavirus cases. Laboratories in the Izabal Health Area have culture media to detect the presence of Coronavirus
On January 31st, Guatemala declares a National Health Alert.
On January 31st, Guatemala Limit entry by air, land and sea to any foreign person who has visited China in the last 15 days.

On January 31st, as part of the National Emergency, Guatemala now allows the admission of any Guatemalan person who has remained in China in the last fifteen days; however, they must comply with the established health protocol, which includes: interview, clinical evaluation, and if necessary, transfer to a MSPAS health service, for proper isolation and treatment.

On January 31st, Guatemala announces that the Minister of National Defense will monitor seaports and ships entering Guatemalan waters. The collection of relevant travel information and the health monitoring of all crew members will be done by the army. Cargo can still be unloaded but crew members are not allowed to exit the boats.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 1st, the boat Green Star was allowed to dock at a Guatemalan port and unload its cargo after monitoring and health tests were conducted by the Guatemalan army. Crew members were not allowed to leave the boat.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 13th, Guatemala once again reminds the population that there is no confirmed case of the coronavirus in the country, asserting that the MSPAS recently tested a patient at the Hospital General Juan de Dios and discovered she had type A Influenza. Guatemala asks all citizens not to panic and to retrieve all information from official sources.

On February 21st, Guatemala announces that it sent a specialist from the National Health Laboratory to a training session in Mexico to learn how to diagnose a person with the coronavirus. The delivery of diagnostic materials for the detection of the virus (primers and positive controls) was also made. Previously, Guatemala had to send the samples to the CDC in Atlanta in the United States, which could take days to obtain the result; however, now the laboratory can diagnose the virus in a matter of hours.
On the 25th of February, Guatemala declares "coronavirus high alert".

On February 25th, Guatemala urges citizens to adopt preventive measures such as 
● Frequent hand washing
● Scarf sneeze (inner arm angle)
● Avoiding contact with sick people
● Attending a health service, if you have symptoms, such as high fever, cough and difficulty breathing.

On February 26th, Guatemala announces that it has conducted three days of training with 190 health workers from around the country to expand their knowledge about the COVID-19 as well as teach them how to approach patients and properly identify the coronavirus.
On March 1rst, Guatemala announces that it has created an isolated wing in Hospital de Villa Nueva that will take care of 200 future coronavirus patients.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 3rd, Guatemala repeats that it has no suspected coronavirus cases, urges citizens to implement preventive health measures and to not let themselves be fooled by fake news.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 5th, Guatemala affirms that the hospital network is ready, asks the population not to panic, and issues preventive measures the population should adopt such as washing hands, disinfecting surfaces, not touching one's face, etc.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 5th, Guatemala declares a State of Public Calamity through the president's Governmental Decree 5-2020, outlining a prevention plan for the coronavirus.

On March 6th, Guatemala announces the launch of a Prevention Campaign in the education system that will involve principals, teachers, students, parent organizations and local authorities. Flyers, posters, and workshop materials were created and translated into all Guatemalan languages. Regions bordering Mexico are being prioritized.
On March 6th, Guatemala declares a State of Public Calamity through the president's Governmental Decree 5-2020, outlining a prevention plan for the coronavirus.

As part of its State of Public Calamity, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will limit the right of locomotion by fixing and establishing sanitary cordons, limiting the movement of all types of transport, as well as preventing people from leaving or entering affected areas.

As part of its State of Calamity decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will prevent gatherings of people and to prohibit or suspend all kinds of public performances and all kinds of meetings or events that represent a risk to health. Public shows, meetings or events scheduled for Saturday 7 and Sunday 8 March 2020 may be held without any interference, but from Monday 9 requests of authorization for any kind of event will have to be sent to the ministry.

As part of its State of Calamity Decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will establish minimum and maximum prices for items, goods, supplies or services that are related in any way to the prevention, treatment, containment and response to Coronavirus (COVID-19) and related medical procedures.

As part of its State of Calamity Decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that the purchase of goods and supplies is authorized as well as the contracting of services without being subject to the requirements established by the Ley de Contrataciones del Estado y su Reglamento.

As part of its State of Calamity Decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that "donations will be consigned and registered in the name of the State of Guatemala and coordinated by the National Coordinator for Disaster Reduction -CONRED- without being subject to the provisions established in the Ley Orgánica del Presupuesto."
On March 6th, Guatemala raises the country's alert status from yellow to red as the first case of the coronavirus (COVID-19) was recorded in Costa Rica.

On March 6th, Guatemala announces that no passenger from countries with confirmed cases may enter the airport without a clinical epidemiological evaluation. Costa Rica is now part of this list of countries.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 9th, Guatemala announces that it has organized a multidisciplinary workshop for the health staff of private hospitals to better prepare them to deal with Covid19.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 10th, Guatemala informs the population that each person or public and/or private company that wants to carry out events with more than 150 people, must ask for authorization of the activity with 48 to 72 hours of anticipation in the Health Area of their locality.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 10th, Guatemala declares that due to the confusion surrounding mass events, notifying the health departments will be necessary, but no authorization will be issued, because, no case of COVID-19 has been confirmed in Guatemala as of yet. Notifications must be made online 48 hours to 72 hours prior to the event.

On March 10th, Guatemala announces that it will be screening all members of a new "migrant caravan" coming from Honduras, despite this country having no confirmed cases of Covid19. Those who show no signs of the coronavirus will be allowed to pass (?)
On March 11th, Guatemala announces that it will prohibit citizens from Europe, China, Korea and Iran from entering the country, starting on March 12th.
On March 11th, Guatemala announces that Guatemalans coming from Europe who do not present symptoms when arriving in the country will be quarantined for at least 7 days in their homes.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 11th, Guatemala announces that it will prohibit citizens from France, Germany, Spain, Italy, China, Korea and Iran from entering the country, starting on March 12th.
On March 12th, Guatemala bans the entry of people from El Salvador as a measure against Covid19.

On the 12th of March, Guatemala warns the population that on the social network Facebook, a user has circulated a message containing false information on a possible case of Covid19, usurping the logo and name of a media outlet.
On March 14th, Guatemala announces that starting from March 15th that all sporting events must be held behind closed doors as part of the State of Calamity.

On March 14th, Guatemala announces that from March 16th onwards, classes are suspended for three weeks throughout the national education system (public and private), from pre-primary to university level.

On March 14th, Guatemala announces that all religious activities celebrating Holy Week are suspended until further notice, and meetings or groups of more than 100 people are prohibited from March 15th onwards.
On March 14th, Guatemala announces that two 24/7 phone lines are now available for citizens to ask questions and report emergencies.

On the 14th of March, Guatemala announces that all patients affected by the Covid19 are to be accepted by hospitals. The Guatemalan Social Security Institute (IGSS) must attend to any patient who arrives in an emergency or in a critical state, whether affiliated or not, and when he or she is stabilized, he or she will be transferred to the hospital network of the Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance (MSPAS).

On March 14th, Guatemala announces that citizens and residents of the United States and Canada will no longer be able to enter the country starting from March 16th. Japanese residents and citizens are now also prohibited from entering Guatemala.

On March 16th, Guatemala announces that no worker who presents symptoms of Covid19 can apply his minimum labour rights and has the obligation to go immediately to a health center or hospital. The employer is obliged to report the case to 1517 and 1540 for follow-up with the Ministry of Public Health and Social Assistance (MSPAS)."  All work activities must be supervised by the employer.
On March 16th, Guatemala announces that tests for the diagnosis of suspected cases of Covid19 will be done by the health services free of charge.
On March 16th, Guatemala announces all European foreigners are prohibited from entering the national territory.

On March 16th, Guatemala announces that all people over 70 or with
serious conditions will have to work from their
households.
On March 16th, Guatemala announces that it is suspending all work activities in the public and private sectors.
On March 16th, Guatemala announces that it prohibits any type of event, regardless of the number of participants, as well as sporting, social and cultural activities.
On March 16th, Guatemala prohibits the entry of foreigners (from any country) through any border.

event_description: On March 16th, Guatemala announces that from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m., all shops must be closed, except for pharmacies, gas stations and essential basic services.The sale of alcoholic beverages is prohibited from 6 p.m. until 5 a.m. the following day.
On March 16th, Guatemala suspends urban and extra-urban public transport throughout the country.
On March 16th, as part of the State of Calamity, Guatemala prohibits institutional visits to older adults in homes or nursing homes.

On March 16th, Guatemala announces that all outpatient visits to public hospitals are suspended. 

Outpatient services are medical procedures or tests that can be done in a medical center without an overnight stay. The outpatient service for patients with a pre-assigned appointment who access medical care for different types of diagnoses.
On March 16th, as part of the State of Calamity, Guatemala prohibits the hoarding of basic necessities and medicines.
On March 16th, Guatemala closes all borders and suspends all international flights to and from Guatemala for 15 days until March 30th.

On March 21st, Guatemala announces a curfew from 4pm to 4am starting the next day, March 22nd and lasting until March 29th, date at which it could be extended. Those who do not comply with the presidential order risk being arrested by National Civil Police officers and must be transferred to a "court of peace".

Guinea government has suspended air travel from or to Guinea effective 11:59pm on Saturday, March 21, 2020
Guinea government officially declares state of emergency effective 26th March , 2020 and bans all religious ceremonies and sporting events.
Land borders are closed for a period of 30 days. Cross border trade however, is permitted but will be under close supervision
With regard to public places, all preschool, elementary, secondary, vocational and university educational establishments will be closed for a period of fourteen (14) days, renewable if necessary.

In keeping with safeguards to prevent an outbreak, more than a dozen family members of Guyana’s first novel coronavirus [COVID-19] victim (confirmed on March 11, 2020) are quarantined. This was confirmed by 
the Public Relations and Health Promotion Officer within the Ministry of Public Health, Mr. Terrence Esseboom on March 12.

In Guyana, Prime Minister Nagamootoo was appointed to head a National Task Force to coordinate efforts to stop the spread of the virus, which has claimed the life of one imported case from the USA.

The National COVID-19 Task Force headed by the Prime Minister includes the Attorney General and Ministers of Public Health, Public Security, Finance, Foreign Affairs, Education, Communities, Public Infrastructure, Natural Resources, and Citizenship was established on 12th March and completed a national response to the Coronavirus disease.

In Guyana, The Ministry of Education wishes to advise that with effect from Monday, March 16, 2020, all schools will be closed for two weeks. This was later extended on March 23rd in another announcement. The extended closure of schools is April 3, which will lead into the Easter Term vacation which runs from April 06, 2020 – April 17, 2020. Schools are set to reopen on April 20.

The University of Guyana (UG) has also extended its closure to March 30th. No updates on opening have been issued for now.

In Guyana, President David Granger issued sweeping powers that may include the destruction of personal property, compulsory hospitalization, and the spending of monies from the Consolidated Fund to fight the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). He said his directive remains in force until he withdraws it.

President directed that the virus is an infectious disease that requires the Minister of Public Health to restrain, segregate and isolate persons suffering from the disease or, maybe, likely from exposure to the disease.

The Health Minister has also been authorized to ask the Guyana Police Force for help in enforcing the President’s directives.

The Public Health Minister is also required to take steps to prevent the spread of the disease on the seas, rivers, and waters of Guyana and on the high seas within 12 miles of the baseline as well as on land.

In Guyana, The Protected Areas Commission (PAC) and the National Parks Commission (NPC) at this time would like to advise the general public that the Georgetown Zoo will be closed beginning Tuesday 17th March 2020 until further notice.

Please be advised also that the Botanical Gardens and the National Park will remain open as we take extra precautionary measures to ensure that all of our public facilities are fully sanitized.

Guyana to partially close airports amid Coronavirus outbreak. 
Director General of the Guyana Civil Aviation Authority (GCAA) Egbert Fields has announced that airports in the country will be partially shutdown, effective Wednesday, March 18, 2020 – due to the Coronavirus outbreak.

The closure will take effect at midnight and will last for 14 days. The shutdown will mainly apply to incoming international passenger flights at the Cheddi Jagan International Airport (CJIA) and Eugene F Correira International Airport.

The shutdown will not apply to outgoing flights, cargo flights, medevac flights, technical flights, and any other specially authorized flights.

In Guyana, to protect our senior citizens during this period when they are the most vulnerable to the Coronavirus (COVID-19), we are working to implement standardized measures across the Post Offices in every region to treat with the potential threat of the virus effectively.

Of grave concern to the management of the Guyana Post Office Corporation (GPOC), is the trend of thousands of senior citizens accessing pension payments during the first and second day of the new month. 

We are therefore vehemently encouraging senior citizens to refrain from visiting the Post Offices during the first two days of the month unless it is absolutely necessary. Senior citizens can also authorize their family members to uplift their pension payments.

In Guyana, President David Granger, on Thursday (2nd April), announced that in order to strengthen containment measures against COVID-19, with effect from midnight (23:59 hours) on Friday 3rd April 2020, the government will close public gathering at places of entertainment, including bars, clubs, gymnasiums, night clubs, restaurants, and swimming pools, between the hours of 18:00 hours and 06:00 hours (6:00 pm and 6 am).

In Guyana, the Minister of Public Health has issued emergency measures to contain the spread of the Novel Coronavirus.

It will be in effect from April 3 to May 3, 2020. These measures, among other things, supervised the implementation of a 6 pm to 6 am curfew while only catering for the operations of essential services on a 24-hour basis.

With these emergency measures now published all curfews or measures taken by town councils and village/community leaders and others are revoked except those made by the Ministers responsible for Education, Civil Aviation, Maritime, Immigration and Finance.

In Guyana, all ‘in person’ hearings have been suspended until further notice.
“These updated directions in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic are in addition to the Supreme Court of Judicature Practice Directions COVID-19 Emergency Directions, Gazetted on 23rd March, 2020.” The Supreme Court stated in a media release.
With immediate effect, the court said these measures will be in place lasting until April 24, 2020.
