Sierre Leone is enforcing mandatory  quarantine to British Nationals or passengers from countries with over 50 cases of the coronavirus from 16th March. the government discouraged travel of nationals from these countries but if it was essential travel they would be quarantined fir 14 days.
On 16th March, Sierre Leone declared a ban on all public gatherings with 100 people or more.
On March 16th, Sierre Leone prohibited all overseas travel for Government officials.
On March 27th, the government of Sierre Leone announced the the country will be closing its borders fo3 30 days with the exception of cargo vehicles which will be inspected and monitored.
Sierre Leone is indefinitely closing schools and all other learning institutions as of 31st March after recording of the country's first case of the Coronavirus.
Sierre Leone announces three day nationwide lockdown effective from April 4th.
Sierre leone is calling a 12 month state of Public health emergency as of March 24th despite having not recorded any cases of the Coronavirus at that time.

As of January 03, Singapore implements a "temperature screening at Changi airport for inbound travellers arriving on flights from Wuhan, and suspected cases will be referred to hospitals for further assessment".

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: As of January 03, Singapore implements a "temperature screening at Changi airport for inbound travellers arriving on flights from Wuhan, and suspected cases will be referred to hospitals for further assessment".

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: As of January 03, Singapore implements a "temperature screening at Changi airport for inbound travellers arriving on flights from Wuhan, and suspected cases will be referred to hospitals for further assessment".

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: In Singapore, "the Ministry of Health (MOH) will expand temperature screening at Changi Airport and issue Health Advisory Notices for all inbound travellers on flights arriving from China from 22 January 2020".

As of January 20 in Singapore, "Individuals with pneumonia and travel history to Wuhan within 14 days before onset of symptoms will be isolated in hospital as a precautionary measure to prevent transmission, and investigated."

As of January 20, Singapore "MOH and the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) have developed a joint clinical guidance on the novel coronavirus which advises on the management of suspect cases. The guidance has been disseminated to Emergency Department and Infectious Diseases physicians, and public sector hospital laboratories."

From 22 January 2020, Singapore "widened the definition of suspect cases to include persons with:

(i) pneumonia and travel history to China within 14 days before onset of symptoms; or

(ii) acute respiratory infection who had been to any hospital in China, within 14 days before onset of symptoms.

These cases will be isolated in hospital as a precautionary measure to prevent transmission."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: In Singapore, "from 22 January 2020, temperature screening at Changi Airport will also be expanded to all inbound travellers on flights arriving from China, and suspect cases meeting the expanded definition above will be referred to hospitals for further assessment."
From January 22, Singapore will distribute "health advisory posters at land and sea checkpoints"

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: In Singapore, "from 22 January 2020, temperature screening at Changi Airport will also be expanded to all inbound travellers on flights arriving from China, and suspect cases meeting this expanded definition will be referred to hospitals for further assessment."

As of January 21, Singapore Ministry of Health "urged the public to remain vigilant and to adopt good personal hygiene practices. All travellers to China were told to monitor their health closely and seek medical attention promptly if they feel unwell, and also inform their doctor of their travel history."

On January 22, the Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore "advised travellers to avoid non-essential travel to Wuhan. MOH also reminded the public to continue to exercise caution and attention to personal hygiene when travelling to the rest of China.

On January 23, Singapore's Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) said "while self-isolation is not required, preschool staff travelling to China should monitor their health closely for 2 weeks upon return to Singapore. They are advised to wear surgical masks while performing their duties or be redeployed into roles without contact with infants and children, if possible. They should seek medical attention immediately if they feel unwell, and also inform their doctor of their travel history. Preschools are reminded to conduct health checks and monitor the health of children, staff, continue with temperature screening for all children, staff and visitors."

On January 23, Singapore's Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) "strongly advised preschool staff to avoid travelling to Wuhan unless necessary. Preschool operators/principals should monitor their staff travel movements.

In Singapore, "the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has implemented temperature screening at all sea checkpoints carried out by healthcare assistants, including ferry and cruise terminals, PSA Terminals and Jurong Port, for inbound travellers from 24 January 2020, 1200 hours onwards."

From 24 January 2020, 12 noon onwards, Singapore is implementing temperature screening at land checkpoints at Woodlands and Tuas Checkpoints for trains, cars, lorries, buses, motorcycles. Travellers will be checked by on-site healthcare assistants and suspect cases will be referred to hospitals for further assessment.

On January 24, Singapore released a health advisory that said "Singaporeans are advised not to travel to the whole of Hubei Province. MOH also advises Singaporeans to continue to exercise caution and attention to personal hygiene when travelling to the rest of China."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 24, Singapore issued a travel advisory stating "Singaporeans are advised not to travel to the whole of Hubei Province. MOH also advises Singaporeans to continue to exercise caution and attention to personal hygiene when travelling to the rest of China."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 27, Singapore said "​As the 2019-nCoV situation in China continues to evolve, the Ministry of Health advises travellers to defer all non-essential travel to Mainland China."

On January 27, Singapore said told preschool employees who intend to travel overseas, or have returned from overseas in the last 14 days, to "declare their travel plans and travel history to their preschool promptly, and follow other instructions from the preschools."

On January 27, Singapore said "To safeguard the health of all members of the preschool community, preschools are to implement a Leave of Absence (LOA) of 14 days for employees and preschool children returning from Mainland China – on and from 28 January 2020, as well as those who returned within the last 14 days (i.e. from 14 January to 27 January 2020)."

On January 27, Singapore launched a Multi-Ministry Taskforce on Wuhan Coronavirus to "direct the national whole-of-government response to the novel coronavirus outbreak; coordinate the community response to protect Singaporeans and stay vigilant against
the spread of the disease; and work with the international community to respond to the outbreak"

On January 27, Singapore announced that "ICA (Immigration and Checkpoints Authority) officers at Changi and Seletar airports will refer arriving Chinese nationals with passports issued in Hubei province to the health screening stations at the airports for further medical assessment."

On January 28, Singapore announced that "the Ministry of Health (MOH) is contacting all recent travellers from Hubei province who are in Singapore. MOH will assess who among this group are at higher risk and will place them under quarantine. Singapore Citizens, Permanent Residents and foreigners on long-term visas will be quarantined at home or other suitable facilities. Those on short-term visas will be housed at Government Quarantine Facilities."

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 28, Singapore announced that "the Ministry of Health (MOH) is contacting all recent travellers from Hubei province who are already in Singapore. MOH will assess who among this group are at higher risk and will place them under quarantine. Singapore Citizens, Permanent Residents and foreigners on long-term visas will be quarantined at home or other suitable facilities. Those on short-term visas will be housed at Government Quarantine Facilities. All residents and long-term passport holders, returning to Singapore soon, either with travel history in Hubei OR with PRC passports issued in Hubei, will be quarantined at home or other suitable facilities.

On January 28, Singapore announced that "New visitors with travel history in Hubei or with PRC passports issued in Hubei will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore. The issuance of all forms of new visas to those with PRC passports issued in Hubei will be suspended and previously issued short-term and multiple-visit visas, as well as visa-free transit facilities, for those with PRC passports issued in Hubei, will also be suspended with immediate effect."

On January 28, Singapore "will reject all new work pass applications for foreign workers from Hubei until further notice. Existing work pass holders outside of Singapore are asked to defer their return until the situation stabilizes. Employees with work passes will be allowed to return but will be quarantined at home or other suitable facilities upon returning.

On January 29, Singapore released sanitation and hygiene advisories for food establishments, including best practices related to personal hygiene, food hygiene, toilets, housekeeping and refuse management, and pest control

On January 29, Singapore released a Quarantine Order Allowance Scheme  to mitigate financial impact for those who have been served Quarantine Orders under the Infectious Diseases Act. Under the QOA scheme, claims of $100 per day can be made by self-employed people and employers, who have employees issued with Quarantine Orders.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 30, Singapore announced that "New visitors with travel history in Mainland China or with PRC passports issued in Hubei will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore. The issuance of all forms of new visas to those with PRC passports issued in Hubei will be suspended and previously issued short-term and multiple-visit visas, as well as visa-free transit facilities, for those with PRC passports issued in Hubei, will also be suspended with immediate effect.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 31, Singapore announced that "the Ministry of Health (MOH) is contacting all residents and long-term passport holders who're returning from Mainland China and they'll be placed under a 14-day leave of absence upon return. These people should stay at home and avoid social contact."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 31, Singapore "will reject all new work pass applications for foreign workers from Mainland China until further notice. Work pass holders entering Singapore with travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days are required to take a 14-day leave of absence upon arrival in Singapore, and stay at home, avoid social contact,  and where appropriate work remotely via telecommuting arrangements."

On February 01, Singapore announced a care package for taxi and private hire drivers placed under quarantine due to COVID-19. This included "$200 one-off allowance from National Taxi Association (NTA) and National Private Hire Vehicles Association (NPHVA) for members, rental waiver for private hire vehicles by Gojek, Grab, Ryde (private hire car operators) and their fleet partners and a one-off allowance from taxi and private-hire car operators of at least $100"

On February 02, Singapore announced economic measures to support the tourism sector. "hotels that provided accommodation to suspected and confirmed cases of Novel Coronavirus infections will get up to 50 per cent of third-party professional cleaning fees covered by STB, capped at S$20,000 (US$14,638) per establishment for hotels with confirmed cases; and S$10,000 per establishment for hotels with suspected cases. The Hotels Licensing Board will also waive licence fees for hotels for the rest of 2020."
On February 03, Singapore issued an advisory of 14-day Leave of Absence for all preschool children with any household member who is on Home Quarantine Order. "
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

event_description: On February 03, Singapore issued a warning to landlords with tenants under leave of absence/quarantine; "Landlords found to have irresponsibly evicted their residents may face restrictions and even be barred from renting out their flats to foreign work pass holders in future."

On February 3, Singapore issued advisory for precautionary measures in preschools. These included continuation of health checks for for all children, staff and visitors, ensuring  good personal hygiene and environmental hygiene.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 03, Singapore issued an advisory of 14-day Leave of Absence for all preschool children with any household member who is on Home Quarantine Order, as well as an LOA for "14-day Leave of Absence for all preschool staff and children returning from Mainland China: i. on and from 28 January 2020, ii. as well as those who returned within the last 14 days prior to 28 January, i.e. 14 January to 27 January 2020."

On February 04, Singapore took additional precautionary measures to minimise congregation of students in large numbers. "Ministry of Education implemented the following in primary and secondary schools, Special Education (SPED) schools, Junior Colleges and Millennia Institute: suspension of large group and communal activities such as assemblies, camps and mass celebrations, staggered recess time, after school programmes to be held in smaller groups". For preschools, large group and communal activities such as assemblies, excursions, fieldtrips and mass celebrations were also suspended.

On February 7, Singapore raised its risk assessment for COVID-19 to DORSCON Orange. According to the Ministry of Health, "As there are now a few local cases without any links to previous cases or travel history to China, we have stepped up our risk assessment from DORSCON Yellow to DORSCON Orange."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 07, Singapore "suspended all external school activities and inter-school activities until the end of the March school holidays". Additionally, at a school where a teacher tested positive for the virus, "students, teachers and staff who had recently come into contact with the teacher will be issued with a 14-day Leave of Absence (LOA). Co-curricular activities there have also been suspended for two weeks with immediate effect. Instead of lectures, there will be more tutorial size classes. The school is also cleaning and disinfecting the school premises thoroughly."
link: Students, teachers and staff who had recently come into contact with the teacher will be issued with a 14-day Leave of Absence (LOA). Co-curricular activities in VJC have also been suspended for two weeks with immediate effect. Instead of lectures, there will be more tutorial size classes. The school is also cleaning and disinfecting the school premises thoroughly.

event_description: On February 7, Singapore adopted new measures to "ensure the health and safety of our blood donors by screening potential donors and their companions for fever or respiratory symptoms, such as cough or runny nose, as well as their travel history to Mainland China, before they can enter the blood banks or mobile drive premises.

On February 7, Enterprise Singapore, a statutory board under the Ministry of Trade and Industry in Singapore, released a Guide on Business
Continuity Planning for COVID-19, in keeping with latest government advisories.

On February 09, Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) asked financial institutions in Singapore to adopt additional measures and precautions including continuing to maintain effective internal controls across their operations, anticipating and be prepared to manage any increase in demand for certain financial services, informing customers promptly of the availability of services and operating hours and monitoring and supporting staff morale.

On February 08, Singapore put in additional measures to protect preschools, including "Limit visitors entering the premises only to those needed to support the running of preschools (e.g. contractors) and agencies who need to perform essential functions and limiting deployment of staff across centres to prevent transmission between preschools"

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description:
On February, Singapore issued new guidance for travel declarations in a preschool setting and told preschools to "obtain travel declarations and monitor travel plans for preschool staff and children on an ongoing basis.
From 5 February 2020, obtain travel declarations for visitors into the preschool. Ensure that visitors have not travelled to Mainland China in the past 14 days."

On February 8, Singapore "advised event organisers to cancel or defer non-essential large-scale events. For those who proceed, MOH advised that necessary precautionary measures be taken including temperature checks, denying entry to unwell people, ensuring venue is properly facilitated, and maintaining registration lists of guests.

On February 10, Singapore released additional measures for taxis and  private hire cars. "Operators have reminded their drivers to continue to practise good personal hygiene/cleaning and disinfection of their vehicles. Drivers have been advised to wind down their vehicles’ windows when ferrying passengers with flu-like symptoms. Drivers have also been advised to take their temperature twice a day, once before starting work and another time in the course of the day, and those feeling unwell should stop work and see a doctor.

On February 10, Singapore released an advisory for taxi operators regarding temperature checks; "eight temperature screening stations across all taxi operators’ premises will be set up from 11 February 2020.  Taxi drivers whose temperature fall within the acceptable range will receive a sticker for the day to indicate that their temperatures have been checked. Taxi drivers who are identified to be unwell will be asked to seek medical attention immediately and visit the doctor. For private hire car (PHC) drivers, operators will, as a start, require their drivers to take their own temperature and to submit their temperature readings via their mobile applications. Unwell passengers are asked to wear the masks from the 4 masks/household drive the government is doing. the Government is making a one-time contribution of 300,000 surgical masks active taxi and PHC drivers. These masks are intended for drivers to offer to passengers who are unwell but do not have a mask and need a ride to seek medical attention"

On February 10, Singapore released advisories for dormitories to enhance measures to mitigate the spread of the virus. "Key measures include: suspending all mass activities to minimise risk of infections among residents, staggering the usage of common dormitory facilities,
making arrangements for residents on Leave of Absence (LOA) to reside together with others on LOA, in a section of the dormitory that is separate from other residents, or having dedicated rooms for them, and making arrangements for food so that residents on LOA need not leave the premises."
On February 11, Singapore and Malaysia established a joint working group to further enhance cooperation to prevent and control the spread of 2019-novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV).

On February 12, Singapore announced a support program for people on leave of absence. "eligible employers can apply for $100 daily per affected worker for the required duration of paid LOA granted to the employee. Affected workers include Singapore Citizens (SC), Permanent Residents (PR), and Work Pass holders who travelled to mainland China on or before 31 January 2020, and who were placed on LOA upon their return to Singapore on or after 31 January 2020. If telecommuting is available, people should not apply for these funds.

On February 12, Singapore released an advisory supported by the public sector developers, Real Estate Developers’ Association of Singapore, and the Migrant Workers’ Centre, to allow workers living in the dormitories to enter their worksite if they were not close contacts of any infected person.

On March 15, the "Ministry of Health (MOH) has advised the public to defer all travel abroad. Employers and employees should defer all work-related travel plans, and employers should remind employees of MOH’s travel advisory to defer all travel abroad.

On March 25, Singapore restricted entry of foreign domestic workers to reduce the risk of importing the COVID-19 virus. "All employers and employment agencies were strongly urged to defer bringing FDWs into Singapore. To facilitate this, there was an automatic extension to the validities of all in-principle approvals granted by 2 months."

On March 25, Singapore issued advisories for foreign domestic workers brought into the country (under slim chances of approval to do so). "Upon arrival in Singapore, FDWs from overseas must serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at an alternative accommodation, after which their work permits would be issued. For FDWs who transited at or travelled from UK or US and enter Singapore from 25 March 2020, 2359 hrs, they are required to serve their 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at designated facilities.

On March 25, Singapore issued a new notice for foreign domestic workers to "spend their rest day at home during in view of the introduction of social distancing measures. If FDWs agree to spend their rest day at home, employers should not assign work to their FDW on the rest day. If FDWs agree to forgo their rest days, employers must provide compensation in lieu of the rest day. If FDWs have errands that they need to attend to on their rest day, they should be encouraged to take their rest day on a weekday, when public spaces are less crowded."

On March 30, Singapore released a guideline on cleaning and disinfection of hotels, premises and public places where a confirmed case has stayed or has visited. It contains general good practices, notes on wearing personal protective gear while cleaning, cleaning instructions and list of cleaning companies.

On January 27, the Slovak government addresses the novel coronavirus and starts a public awareness campaign. The campaign includes an email address and phone number for the population to contact in case of questions regarding the disease, as well as issuing behavioral recommendations for travelers to risk countries.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On January 29 and February 4, Slovak Ministry of Health expands its public awareness and communication resources dedicated to the coronavirus by multiple hotlines (available 7 days a week). Email capacity is also expanded.

On February 17th, Slovak Government dedicates funds to purchase equipment and improve diagnostic capabilities of specialized medical centers. Practices in Slovak hospitals in preparation for an eventual outbreak of the coronavirus are also planned as of February 10.

On February 24, Slovak Government announces measures regarding all planes landing in Slovakia from Italy. All passengers will be asked to fill out a form which would store their information in the case they would need to be contacted later on. Passengers are also encouraged to make use of the coronavirus callcenter hotlines should they have any questions or concerns.
On February 27, first meeting of the Crisis Council  in connection to the novel coronavirus takes place. The body will assess and monitor the situation closely on a daily basis.

On February 27, Slovak Government advises citizens to reconsider travel to risk countries (list of which is issued and continually updated by Slovak Foreign Ministry). Emergency SMS will be sent to travelers upon return to inform them of COVID-19 prevention measures.

Citizens who have recently traveled are advised to monitor their symptoms for at least 14 days and contact their doctor via telephone or email should they observe symptoms similar to those of COVID-19.

On March 6, Slovak Government advises against visiting hospitals and retirement homes. In addition, it plans sending an emergency SMS to all telephone numbers registered in Slovakia in order to inform citizens about prevention measures. Ministry of Health has compiled several versions of information leaflets which are available at doctor's offices and handed out at border crossings.

On March 9, Slovak Government announces a ban on public, cultural and sporting events, to last 14 days with the possibility of extension. In addition, all travelers returning from Italy, Iran, China or South Korea should self-isolate together with their families.
ON March 12, Slovak government announces intention to close schools and universities beginning Monday March 16, to be upheld for at least 14 days.

On March 12, Slovak government announces the closure of non-essential businesses, including ski resorts, wellness centers, amusement parks, swimming pools, bars, clubs and cultural centers. Over the weekend, citizens can only buy food, groceries and medicine in shopping malls.
Slovakia government restricts opening hours in some governmental offices and bureaus.

On March 12, Slovak Government announces the closure of all three international airports. Temporary border checks will also be instated on land border crossings with all neighbor countries except for Poland - only citizens or long-term residents will be allowed into the country. All arriving travelers need to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after their arrival.
On March 12, Slovak Government announces (further unspecified) restrictions on travel via bus and train.

On March 15, Slovak government announces the state of emergency in 22 state-run hospitals spread throughout all regions. This enables the government to control and move health resources and personnel according to the regional concentration of COVID-19 infections.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 15, Slovak government advises hospitals to limit planned surgeries and restrict elective care services for the duration of the state of emergency.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 17, Slovak government and Slovak Ministry of Health decided to extend state of emergency to private hospitals and private healthcare providers.
Slovak crisis council advises owners of businesses, stores, buildings and managers of public transport infrastructure to ask their employees / customers to wear a medical mask.

Slovak government decided that COVID-19 testing will be fully centralized controlled by the state. Private laboratories and testing companies are prepared to help, but will not sell testing kits or test patients for a fee. Overall, there are 4 testing centers throughout Slovakia, each with the capacity of 700 tests a day.
On March 24, Slovak Government decides that residents should only appear in public with a mask covering their mouth and face.
On March 24, Slovak Government mandates citizens to maintain 2 meters distance away from each other when standing in a queue.
On March 24, Slovak Government ruled that there are to be temperature checks at the entrance of hospitals, shops, factories and places where people gather.

Slovak Government ruled that there are to be 3 specialized COVID-19 hospitals established - one in the east, central region and west of the country. In other hospitals, there is to be an independent ward / pavilion to be established exclusively for COVID-19 patients.
Slovak police and army are to assist in the logistical management of hospitals most hit by the coronavirus.

On March 24, Slovak Government announced that all hospitals which carry out coronavirus testing will set up a testing station in their parking lot, so that samples can be taken without patients leaving their vehicles.
On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to ban the export of essential health materials, both protective and therapeutic.

Slovak Government instates a state of emergency in retirement homes, placing heightened hygiene measures. Senior citizens are advised to self-quarantine in their home and limit physical contact with all persons, including family members. Municipalities are to set up special call lines through which senior citizens could order deliveries of food and groceries.
On March 24, Slovak government announces shopping hours (between 9am and 12pm) exclusively for citizens over 65 years of age.
On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to cooperative with mobile network providers and send emergency messages with COVID-19 information directly to the phones of vulnerable citizens.

On March 24, Slovak Government announces that all shops which remain in operation are to be closed on Sundays. The purpose of this policy is to use the day to disinfect store facilities as well as alleviate the strain on workers employed in essential businesses.

Slovak medical administration will give priority to licensing COVID-19 testing and treatment. New proposed therapeutics will be prioritized and their approval process will be streamlined as much as (safely) possible.

On March 28 the Slovak government introduced additional hygienic measures to be upheld in stores. Everyone present inside the store has to be wearing a mask, either hand sanitizer gel or disposable gloves are to be available to all customers and employees. Only a limited number of customers are allowed into the store at a time - specifically, one customer per 25 square meters. Temperature checks are not mandated, but advised.
If such measures are to be upheld, some restrictions on non-essential businesses may be lifted in the near future.
Minister of Health of Slovenia signs an Order banning gatherings of more than 500 people at public events in indoor public places.
The government of Slovenia recommends event organisers to ban events of fewer than 500 people from March 7.
Slovenia prohibits indoor public gatherings for 100-plus visitors from March 3., with the exception of shopping malls, small commercial venues, weddings, funerals and religious ceremonies.

Slovenia bans aircrafts from Italian airports, in places where risk of infection is higher, from China, South Korea, and Iran. The ban applies from 10. 3. 2020 to 31. 3. 2020, with a possibility of extension. This does not apply to emergency and medical flights.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

event_description: Slovenia sets up a call centre to assist inhabitants in finding information regarding the coronavirus.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that all preventive activities of health centres at Metlika, Novo mesto, Črnomelj and at Novo mesto general hospital will be suspended and all non-urgent specialist examinations will be rescheduled until further notice, except for acute illnesses and conditions that could lead to a deterioration of health. Visits to a personal doctor should be made by prior telephone appointment.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that employers should alert or urge workers who are ill to stay at home and follow instructions. Work from home is advised to the greatest possible extent. Non-urgent business trips are strongly advised against.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that "all travellers crossing the Slovenian border will be informed via SMS notification of the preventive measures in force in this country regarding the coronavirus" and "leaflets containing coronavirus action instructions will be distributed to all Slovenian households via the Post of Slovenia."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 9, Slovenia announced that it will amend the Order prohibiting indoor public gatherings to reduce the upper limit from 500 to 100 people from March 10.
On 10 March, Slovenia advises citizens against travelling to the South Korean area around Daegu and Cheongju and against all but essential travel to other parts of the Republic of Korea.
On March 10, Slovenia advises "against all but essential travel to China and against all travel to the province of Hubei until further notice."
On March 10, the Slovenian MFA advises against all travel to Italy.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On 10 March, the Slovenian MFA advised against all travel to Iran. Slovenian citizens temporarily staying in Iran are advised to leave the country as soon as possible.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On 10 March, the Slovenian MFA advised against all travel to Iran. Slovenian citizens temporarily staying in Iran are advised to leave the country as soon as possible.

The Slovenian government adopted a decision to start carrying out border control checks in the vicinity of the border between Slovenia and Italy on 11 March 2020. This will include checking for negative SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) result certificates issued by a competent authority.
On March 11, "Passenger train traffic between Italy and Slovenia has been suspended."
On March 12 at 6 p.m., Slovenia declares an epidemic. At the same time, the national emergency response plan is activated.

On March 12, Slovenia prohibits health staff from taking annual leave, restricts their right to go on strike and the right to participate in training and education provided in infected areas or areas at immediate risk of coronavirus outbreaks
On March 12, the Civil Protection Service of the Republic of Slovenia was put in charge of coordinating the measures to combat the spread of the virus, in cooperation with the relevant departments.
On March 12, the Government of Slovenia adopted the decision to temporarily close kindergartens and schools between March 16 and March 29.

On March 12, Slovenia announced that "As of 16 March 2020, specialist examinations and surgical operations except cases rated as “emergency” or “urgent” or “express” will be cancelled. This will exclude oncology and pregnancy treatments. Wherever there is a possibility of e-consulting services, it should be used to the maximum extent."

On March 14, Slovenian "Prime Minister Janez Janša said that the Government established the crisis unit to contain and manage the COVID-19 epidemic at its first session [...]. The crisis unit will include support groups, the most important of which will consist of medical experts."
On March 14, Slovenian government froze the prices of protective equipment in order to achieve a reasonable cost for individual items.
On March 14, Slovenia announces a change in diagnostics, where the number of severely ill persons requiring hospital care will be monitored through testing, not the total number of infected persons.
On March 15, Slovenia places a temporary ban on public transport of passengers, with the exception of auto-taxi services.

On March 15, Slovenia announces a temporary ban on the provision and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the territory of the Republic of Slovenia from March 16 at 00.00. The temporary ban excludes remote provision and sale of goods and services to consumers and certain activities such as pharmacies, stores with food, shops with medical devices, petrol stations, banks, post offices, delivery services.

A grocery store is a store that mostly sells groceries."

On March 24, Slovenia announces setting up of thirteen checkpoints at the border with Austria from March 25.  Entry to Slovenia will be permitted only to foreign citizens with a recent health certificate or to those with body temperature under 37.5C and no clear signs of respiratory infection. This excludes Slovenian citizens.
On March 27, the Slovenian government announced all Slovenians returning from coronavirus hotspots would be put into state-administrated quarantine.

event_description: On March 29, Slovenia entered into force a law allowing a one-month suspension of a prison sentence and an early release of prisoners up to six months before the end of their sentence.
On March 29, Slovenia announces the mandatory use of masks (or equivalents, such as scarves that cover the mouth and nose) and protective gloves in indoor public spaces.

On April 3, the Slovenian Government announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for most people entering the country from April 4, punishable by fines. It does not, however, apply to people who have to travel for work, those involved in cargo traffic or who are passing through Slovenia on their way to another country without staying overnight.

On April 4, The Defence Ministry announced that the rotations of contingents of the Slovenian Armed Forces in international operations and missions planned in the next three months will not be carried out. The contingents which are currently abroad will need to extend their service for three months. Around 250 troops are deployed in Kosovo and eight in Mali.

On April 4, The Slovenian government restricted the usage of drugs containing chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine or azithromycin to make sure enough of those substances are available to patients who need them.

The Solomon Islands Government has currently designated only Honiara and Noro Ports as the only approved Entry and Exit Points of Clearance.

All cargo ships, including all logging, mineral ores and fishing vessels must serve the 14 day period off shore and can only be cleared after that period. 
3Clearance under shall be conditioned to presentation of mandatory minimum documentation as requested by the Solomon Islands Government.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The Solomon Island Government declares that no cruise liners and yachts are allowed to enter the country for a period of 90 days.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Originally anyone who travelled from or transited through "Restricted Countries" 14 days before their arrival in Solomon Islands will not be permitted to enter, now Effective immediately all non-citizens will not be permitted to enter the Solomon Islands.

1.2  Incoming Solomon Islands Citizens and residents who travelled through any country reporting cases of COVID-19(Coronavirus) will be permitted to enter however, will undergo mandatory strict quarantine for 14 days. 
1.3 Upon arrival all travelers and crew must provide details of their international travel history for the period of 14 days prior to arrival in Solomon Islands. 
1.4 Any traveler or crew who is preparing to travel to the Solomon Islands should self-assess their health, and if thought to display symptoms of the COVID-19 virus, are strongly advised not to travel.  
1.5 Any air crew upon or after arrival in the Solomon Islands is mandated to report to Health authorities if they become unwell and display symptoms of the COVID-19 during the 14-day period after arrival. 
1.6  Clause 1.1 shall not apply to Authorised Personnel with prior written approval of the Prime Minister. 
2. Pre-arrival screening measures: 
2.1  The pilot or ship master of all aircraft/ vessels coming to Solomon Islands are mandated to report, upon arrival, presence of any sick person on board (symptoms or signs of flu, running nose, fever, headache, chest pain, difficulty in breathing, or rash) using health declaration part of aircraft general declaration or Maritime Declaration of Health as applicable.  
2.2  All persons including crew arriving in Solomon Islands either by air or sea MUST complete a Traveller’s Public Health Declaration Card.  
 3 
2.3  All travellers arriving in Solomon Islands will be quarantined for 14 days and are mandated to report presence or development of any symptoms within 14 days of arrival in Solomon Islands. Persons suspected of or displaying any symptoms of the COVID-19 will be isolated and subjected to future diagnosis or tests by Health Authorities. Any quarantine/ isolation station and period shall be determined and/or directed by Health Authorities. 
2.4  All incoming travellers MUST complete a Travellers Public Health Declaration and also provide full details of their place of stay, travel itinerary and current personal contact details in Solomon Islands for 14 days after their arrival in Solomon Islands.

The government has established an oversight committee to address the Covid-19 threat.
The oversight committee comprises of senior officials and experts from various government ministries and agencies.
The committee for Covid-19 is also conducting public awareness on Covid-19 and measles through various media outlets.
The Solomon Island Government is closuring all Schools in Honiara and Guadalcanal to proceed on an early school break from Friday 20 March.
All traditional and non-traditional Border travelers using the Solomon Islands – PNG border are advised this border crossing will be closed effective Friday 20 March 2020.

Non-essential government services will be scaled down following an assessment by Permanent Secretaries, and in the case of Honiara City Council and Guadalcanal Province, the City Clerk and the Provincial Secretary of Guadalcanal Province respectively.
Non-essential public gatherings including sporting events, fun-raising concerts, weddings, night clubs, kava bars are discouraged.
All citizens in the provinces are advised to NOT undertake any non-essential travel to Honiara with immediate effect.
Solomon Island government is closing Kukum Market and Fishing Village market indefinitely from Monday 23rd March 2020.
A week-long State of Emergency was announced, starting from 25 March

The Solomon Government authorized public servants under the non-essential services  to take emergency paid leave of absence from work starting on March 31 until further notice.
After a 30 days leave period, public officers’ remuneration will be on half-pay until they are recalled to duty. On resumption to duty, officers’ salaries will be reinstated in full while the other 50% salary withheld during emergency leave will also be repaid in full.

Prime Minister Hon. Manasseh Sogavare has declared Honiara an emergency zone on March 27. He said other orders with immediate effect under the regulation are the closure of
nightclubs, kava bars, bars and casinos.

On January 26th, Sri Lanka announced testing criteria for Novel Coronavirus (nCoV): 1) Patients with severe acute respiratory infection (fever, cough, and requiring admission to hospital), AND with no other aetiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND at least one of the following: 
a. history of travel to or residence in the city of Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or
b. Patient is a heath care worker who has been working in an environment  where severe acute respiratory infections of unknown aetiology are being cared for. 
2) Patients with any acute respiratory illness AND at least one of the following: 
a. close contact with a confirmed or probable case of 2019-nCoV in the 14 days prior to illness onset, or 
b. visiting or working in a live animal market in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or 
c. Worked or attended a health care facility in the 14 days prior to onset of symptoms where patients with hospital-associated 2019-nCov infections have been reported.

On January 26th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that all passengers from flights originated from China need to be screened for temperature. If a passenger with elevated temperature is detected, he/she should be given a surgical mask to wear and taken to the health office. 

All suspected 2019-nCoV patients need to be screened by airport health office (APHO) medical officers. Consent for examination and further assessment should be obtained from the traveler or parent of guardian. If consent is not given, the traveler/s will be managed under the authority given by the Quarantine and Prevention of Diseases Ordinance. 

If the traveler has a contact history and fever/signs and symptoms, the traveler should be transferred to IDH/ designated hospitals.Director or a designed officer from these hospitals should immediately contact the Chief Epidemiologist and the D Quarantine and should immediately provide relevant patient information for required surveillance, prevention and further actions.

Passengers Locator Form should be filled for those travelers with suspected nCoV seated in the same row and two rows in front and behind the index suspected case. The details should be communicated to the Epidemiology Unit, which will carry out the community level contact tracing and house quarantine of asymptomatic contacts with the help of Regional Epidemiologist and MOOH.

The government of Sri Lanka announced that all international airports in Sri Lanka will be closed to arriving international commercial passenger flights from 19 March to 25 March, 2020, which has been subsequently extended.

Sri Lanka declared March 20th to 27th as ‘Work from home week’ for both public and private sectors.

This duration is not public holidays except March 21st and 22nd.
Sri Lanka's Presidential Secretariat announced that curfew will be imposed country-wide from 6.00 pm (March 20) until 6.00 am on Monday (March 23).

Sri Lanka inaugurated 'National Operation Centre for Prevention of COVID-19 Outbreak' (NOCPCO) on March 21st, 2020. the Centre is established on the guidelines given by HE the President Gotabaya Rajapaksa with the objective of centralizing, expediting and implementing all necessary preventive and containing measures against the transmission of COVID - 19 pandemic. This Centre is headed by Lieutenant General Shavendra Silva, Chief of Defence Sta􀃠 and Commander of the Army.

The Sri Lanka Telecommunication Regulatory Commission stated on March 23rd that, based on TRCSL guidance all operators have agreed and now have a mechanism to provide emergency credit and extra talk time for prepaid customers who may face difficulty purchasing top-ups due to curfew.

The TRCSL also said that, “All operators have agreed to provide uninterrupted services for all customers inline. “

Sri Lanka President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had set up a special fund “COVID – 19 Healthcare and Social Security Fund” to strengthen the mitigation activities aimed at controlling the spread of COVID-19 virus in the country and related social welfare programmes.

President Rajapaksa has instructed to donate Rs. 100 million from the President’s Fund for this purpos

Sri Lanka established the Presidential Task Force on March 26th to combat COVID – 19 with the responsibility to ensure that the civilian life moves on without any hindrance. 

The Special Representative of the President Basil Rajapaksa has been appointed as the Chairman of the Task Force while Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister Anton Perera serves as the Secretary.

The membership of the Task Force is 40 including Provincial Governors, several Secretaries to Ministries, Commanders of Tri-Forces, security chiefs including Acting Inspector General of Police, Chairmen of several Departments, Corporations and Authorities and District and Divisional Secretaries.

The President had declared powers and functions of the Task Force through a special gazette notification.

The Task Force should carry out its responsibilities covering every district in the country while giving priority to districts of Colombo, Kalutara, Gampaha, Puttalam, Jaffana, Mannar, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya and Mullaitivu which have been identified as fasing a greater risk.

event_description: The federal council of Switzerland votes to ban large-scale mass gatherings of 1000 people or more on February 28th, 2020. The ban will last until at least March 15th 2020.
The Swiss Federal council release recommendations on social distancing and avoiding unnecessary exposure to individuals over the age of 60 with pre-existing health conditions on March 6th 2020.
The Swiss Federal council announces on March 13th that all schools will be closed effective immediately until at least April 4th.

On March 13th 2020, the Swiss federal council decides to close all ski resorts effective on March 14th 2020. Previously different cantons had been making their own decisions regarding ski resort closure.

On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter Italy. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy.

event_description: The Swiss Federal Council appoints a scientific advisory board, made up of researchers from higher education and private scientific sector who aim to improve the situation regarding COVID-19 in Switzerland from March 31st 2020 onwards.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to temporarily change the regulation on electronic signatures. The change provides a general way of video identification when issuing certificates, making physical signatures redundant. This way, trips and personal contacts can be avoided

The Swiss Federal Council has made adjustments to the asylum procedure in Switzerland which is to be coordinated across all cantons from April 1st 2020. The changes include greater physical distance in the asylum interview process (fewer individuals in the room etc) and additional accommodation for asylum applicants who are unable to leave due to COVID-19 to be made by converting military accommodation.

The Swiss Federal Council is giving the Confederation more powers to coordinate the supply of important medical goods to combat the corona virus, including the obligation of individual cantons to report medical supply stocks in order to avoid bottlenecks in supply, enacted on April 3rd 2020
The Syrian Ministry of Endowments on March 14 announced the suspension of Friday prayers and group prayers for two weeks.

On March 18, the Recruitment Directorate affiliated with the Syria regime forces announced the suspension of the issuance of driver's licenses and military service completion attestations until April 22.
On March 20, the Ministry of Religious Endowments decided to close all directorates and divisions from March 22 to April 2.
On March 20, the government banned entry for foreigners, after the first coronavirus victim reached Syria by road from Lebanon after returning from Europe.
Health officials have deployed medical teams at the national level and to 1,864 health clinics across the country.
On March 23, the government stepped up procedures for the supposed response to the epidemic by carrying out campaigns to sterilize cities and villages.
Taiwan is enforcing health testing on passengers traveling directly from Wuhan before leaving the plane since Dec. 31 2019.
Taiwan CDC monitors all individuals who had traveled to Wuhan within 14 days and exhibited a or symptoms of upper respiratory tract infections on Jan. 5.

Taiwan CDC raises the travel notice level for Wuhan City to Level 1: Watch and advice travelers planning to visit Wuhan or other neighboring areas in China recently to avoid contact with wild animals and poultry, avoid visiting live poultry markets and consuming undercooked meats, and avoid contact with patients and wash hands thoroughly with soap on Jan, 07.

Taiwan CDC has raised the travel notice level for Wuhan City to Level 2: Alert, advising travelers planning to recently visit Wuhan and other neighboring areas in China to take personal precautions to ward off infection on Jan. 16.
Taiwan CDC announces the activation of the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) for Severe Special Infectious Pneumonia on Jan. 20.
Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) raises the travel notice level for Wuhan, China to Level 3: Warning on Jan. 21.

Taiwan CDC advice all travelers from China, Hong Kong and Macau to take voluntary health assessment and notify the quarantine officer at the quarantine station in the airport/port if symptoms such as fever or cough develop.
On Jan. 23 Taiwan Ministry of Economic Affairs imposes a ban on face masks of textile materials exports for a month from Jan 24 to Feb. 23. The ban was extend to April 30 on Feb. 13.

Taiwan CECC broadens the travel notice to Hubei Province (including Wuhan City) and raised the level for Hubei Province to Level 3: Warning on Jan 25. The public is advised to avoid non-essential trips to the area.
Taiwan CECC  raises travel notice level for other Chinese provinces to Level 2: Alert on Jan. 25. Travelers planning to visit China are advised to reinforce prevention measures.
Taiwan CECC stipulates restrictions on entry of Chinese citizens on Jan. 26.
Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for China (excluding Hong Kong, Macau) to Level 3: Warning; public advised to avoid non-essential travels to China on Jan. 28.
Taiwan CDC announces to electronically monitor (track by phone) potential coronavirus patients who are under home quarantine on Jan. 29.

Taiwan Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announces that it would release 6 million of masks, but limit each person to buying a maximum of three at four major convenient stores and pharmacies on Jan. 28.

Taiwan CECC issues relevant guidance for public transportation, public gatherings, schools and educational institutions and groups and provided advice on prevention measures to reduce the risk of infection on Jan. 29.
Taiwan CDC and the HTC Corporation’s healthcare unit DeepQ  launches an official LINE chatbot Disease Control Butler (疾管家) to provide epidemic information on Jan. 29.
Taiwan CECC urges travelers to conduct self-health management for 14 days after returning to Taiwan and report suspected symptoms to the CDC hotline on Jan. 20.

Taiwan Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has issued a requisition for  companies that have medical equipment licenses and factory registration certificates on Jan. 31. For the remaining 37 mask manufacturers who have production facts but are relatively small, the Ministry of Health and Welfare (MOHW) has also issued the fourth batch of mask requisitions. The mask production of 66 companies with production facts has been fully requisitioned on Feb 13.

on Jan. 31 Taiwan Executive Yuan launches special funding (about 200 million NTD) to purchase mask production equipments building 60 mask production lines to reach the total daily mask production capacity of 10 million pieces per day.

On Feb. 01 Taiwan CECC categorizes different parts of China into two levels based on the severity of 2019-nCoV outbreak: Level 1 Area and Level 2 Area. Level 1 Area indicates areas with significant community transmission which is hard to control, and Hubei province has been listed as Level 1 Area. Taiwan CECC raises outbreak level for Guangdong province to Level 2. Travelers with history of travel to Guangdong required home quarantine for 14 days

Taiwan CECC determines that all primary and secondary schools will postpone the first day of spring semester until 2 weeks later to minimize the risk of the spread of the disease and ensure students’ health on Feb. 02.

Taiwan CECC determines to list Wenzhou as Level 2 Area starting from Feb. 3. Travelers with a history of travel to Wenzhou City are subject to home quarantine when they enter Taiwan and that Wenzhou residents are prohibited from entering Taiwan.
Taiwan CECC requisitiones masks (including for children) and allocated masks to the local government health bureau to meet emergency epidemic prevention needs on Feb. 2.

Taiwan CECC announces that a name-based rationing system for face masks will be launched on February 6, 2020 to ensure universal access to face masks as well as fairness and transparency of resources allocation on February 3.
Taiwan Ministry of Education announces that the start of spring semester will be postponed till Feb. 25 for universities and higher educations on Feb. 03.
Taiwan CECC announces that Zhejiang province to be listed as Level 2 Area from February 5; travelers with history of travel to Zhejiang required to conduct home quarantine on Feb. 04.
Taiwan CECC announces strict border control: cruise ships docking in China, Hong Kong or Macau 14 days prior to arrival barred from entry on Feb. 05.

Taiwan CDC announces that starting from 0:00 am of February 10, 2020, travelers who transit through China, Hong Kong and Macau and are granted entry into Taiwan and will be required to be under home quarantine for 14 days on Feb 07.

Taiwan CECC announces that travel notice for  Hong Kong and Macau has been raised to Level 3: Warning; for Singapore has been raised to Level 2: Alert; for Thailand has been raised to Level 1: Watch, and the public is advised to practice usual precautions on Feb.11.

Taiwan CECC announces that travelers entering Taiwan to be required to complete health declaration form and accurately provide their travel and contact history regarding whether they have visited China, Hong Kong and Macau over the past 14 days before entry on February 11.

Taiwan CECC announces that since February 12, COVID-19 testing has become a mandatory procedure for severe complicated influenza cases, cases of community-acquired upper respiratory infections under surveillance and clusters of upper respiratory infections who were reported on and after January 31 and whose specimens tested negative.
Taiwan CDC raises the travel notice level for Japan to Level: 1 Watch and the public is advised to practice usual precautions om Feb. 14.

in order to expedite the process of quarantine operations and immigration clearance upon arrival, Taiwan CDC has developed the Passenger Health Declaration and Home Quarantine Information System (Entry Quarantine System) and will launch the system soon. Travelers with mobile phone numbers provided by telecom operators in Taiwan can use the Entry Quarantine System by scanning the QR Code while waiting at the check-in counter

Taiwan CECC announces that starting February 16 (Sunday), face masks to be purchased at local health centers in addition to pharmacies on Feb. 15. Face masks supplied under the name-based system can be purchased at 303 local district public health centers

event_description: To strengthen community-based surveillance, Taiwan CECC announces that groups with foreign travel or contact history or other groups of potential risks will be included in COVID-19 testing procedure.
On Feb. 17, Taiwan CECC announces that children to be allowed for 4 masks every week due to increased mask production and start of new semester starting from Feb 20.

Under close coordination between the Taiwan CECC, the Environmental Protection Administration and the Ministry of Education, local environmental protection departments have been tasked with disinfecting public spaces surrounding schools and public kindergartens and spaces in light of the start (Feb. 25) of the new semester on Feb 19.

Taiwan CDC together with  Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) announce that public transportation ridership should be disinfected on Feb. 19. Carriages of the Taiwan High Speed Rail (THSR) and Taiwan Railways (TR) should be cleaned and disinfected at least once a day; points of frequent contact inside THSR carriages (e.g., armrests, tables) once each round trip; and points of frequent contact in metro carriages once every eight hours.

Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for South Korea raised to Level 1: Watch in light of the clusters of cases reported in South Korea on Feb 20. The public is advised to practice usual precautions.
Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for Japan and South Korea to Level 2: Alert on Feb 22; travelers to the countries are advised to practice enhanced precautions.

Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for Iran and Italy to Level 1:Watch. Travelers to Iran and Italy are advised to practice usual precautions. Medical personnel are advised to postpone any travel plans for these two countries
Taiwan CECC advices medical personnel to postpone any travel plans for Italy and Iran on Feb. 23.

on Feb 23 Taiwan CDC announces that to carry out proper home quarantine measures and improve the care services, a new task force "Home Quarantine Service Program" is launched together with 22 local governments. The program will provide the tagerts medical assistance, transport services, basic supplies supports, hotline service, etc.

Taiwan CDC announces that In response to the development of the epidemic, medical personnel will be restricted from going abroad on Feb. 23. The target of the restriction will be mainly medical personnel directly related to the care of patients in the hospital.

on Feb. 24 Taiwan CECC stresses that according to the Communicable Disease Control Act and related measures, travelers with history of travel to China, Hong Kong and Macau are required to undergo home quarantine for 14 days from their arrival date and shall provide correct contact information to health authorities and adhere to relevant requirements. The CECC has utilized smart technologies to help track people under home quarantine to ensure the measure to be followed, the CECC stated today. Those who violate relevant requirements for home quarantine by going outside will be fined up to NT$150,000.

on Feb. 24 Taiwan CECC announces that travelers arriving from countries under Level 1 and Level 2 travel warning subject to 14-day self-health management. Travel notice level 1: Thailand, Italy and Iran
Travel notice level 2: Singapore and Japan
On Feb. 24 Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for South Korea to Level 3: Warning, advises against all non-essential travel.
Taiwan CECC announces that starting from February 27, Taiwanese nationals entering Taiwan from South Korea must undergo a 14-day period of home quarantine on Feb. 24.

In response to the reopening of schools, the Taiwan CECC made adjustments to the distribution of child-size face masks under the current rationing plan to reinforce prevention efforts for children and allow parents to buy child-size face masks readily starting from 27th on Feb 25.

Taiwan CECC announces on Feb 25. that it has raised the travel notice for Italy to Level 2: Alert, in the wake of the rapid increase in the number of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases in the country. The CECC advised travelers to take enhanced precautions when visiting Italy.
Taiwan CECC raises travel notice level for Iran to Level 2: Alert; travelers advised to practice enhanced precautions.

On March 1, Taiwan CECC announces that starting from March 2, travelers who have traveled to Iran in the past 14 days (transits not included) are required to follow a 14-day home quarantine after entering Taiwan.

On March 2, Taiwan CECC announces that starting March 5, everyone to be allowed for one additional face mask every week due to increased production. Adults will be eligible for three face masks and children will be allowed for five masks every seven days, under name-based system.

under the guidance of the National Security Conference of the Presidential Office, the Homeland Security Office of the Executive Yuan and experts, the Taiwan CECC jointly develop the "Enterprises in Response to Serious Special Infections Guidelines for the Continuous Operation of Epidemic Pneumonia (COVID-19)" on March 05 to reduce the impact of the epidemic on the operation of the enterprise.

Taiwan CECC raised its travel notice level to Level 2: Alert for France, Germany and Spain, in the wake of rapid increases in the numbers of coronavirus disease on March 7. The CECC also advised travelers visiting these countries to take enhanced precautions.
Taiwan CECC advices travelers entering Taiwan from France, German, and Spain are subject to a 14-day period of self-health management on March 07.

Taiwan CECC announces on March 10 that an online ordering mechanism will be added to the name-based rationing system for face masks on March 12. The mechanism will allow people to order at a designated website using their NHI card or Citizen Digital Certificate or through the NHI app other than pharmacies.

Taiwan CECC raises travel notice for certain European, Middle Eastern countries (Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Denmark, Iceland, Kuwait, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland) to Level 2: Alert; travelers advised to take adequate precautionary measures on March 11.

Taiwan CECC announces that travelers returning to Taiwan from any of the countries (Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Denmark, Iceland, Kuwait, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland) must observe a 14-day period of self-health management on March 11.

On March 11 Taiwan CECC raises travel notice to Level 1: Watch for the following countries: the Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Ireland and the United Kingdom; visitors to the countries listed above to take usual precautionary measures.

Bahamas 18 March 2020
The new emergency measures are to save lives and to protect The Bahamas, and are included in the Emergency Powers (COVID-19) Regulations, 2020, passed in the House of Assembly on Wednesday 18 March.
 
The major components of the Regulations include:
 
Health Officers have been empowered to take certain actions to prevent the spread of the disease
Where a health officer believes that someone is infected, they may order such a person detained for screening and assessment.  The officer is also empowered to impose the necessary restrictions of movement to prevent further spread of infection.
Where the infected is a minor, a parent or guardian will be responsible for ensuring compliance with any restriction of movement.
A health officer can order isolation on reasonable grounds in order to prevent further spread of the disease.
Public gatherings may be restricted
Under the emergency proclamation, permits for use of public spaces can be suspended nationally in the interest of public safety. This suspension can cover an assembly of as little as two persons in public areas.
Public movement may be restricted
The Prime Minister may also impose isolation or confine persons to their homes. Under these circumstances, all educational and religious institutions would be closed. Certain businesses and other entities catering to the public may be ordered closed. Visits to residential care establishments such as senior care facilities would be prohibited. Visits to correctional facilities would be prohibited. Trips to the grocery store, gas station, pharmacy, doctor, hospital may be regulated or limited to certain times. 
Curfews may also be imposed if necessary.
 
Certain areas may have access restricted
Under the emergency proclamation persons may be restricted from entering certain areas in the interest of public safety, in order to keep the peace or to allow the ease of distribution of necessary supplies.
Vehicles and buildings may be requisitioned by the Government
The Prime Minister may requisition any buildings, aircraft or marine vessel or any other craft as necessary.
Essential services may be requisitioned
Essential services, whether public or private, may be requisitioned under this proclamation. These include:
Water collection, storage, purification or distribution 
The collection, storage and treatment of sewage or garbage
The manufacture, storage or distribution of gas for public use
The removal, handling and burial of the dead
The removal, handling and burial of dead animals
Certain laws may be waived
To facilitate the government's procurement of needed goods, rules or laws related to such procurement may be waived.  Under such circumstances, within six weeks, the Ministry of Finance would be required to give a proper accounting related to the procurement.
Certain fees may be waived
The Prime Minister may also waive or vary the payment of any fees for the testing and medical services rendered at any public hospital or healthcare facility in relation to Covid-19.
The dissemination of malicious and misleading information is prohibited
Under these regulations, no person shall publish or cause to be published, posted or re-posted over any media platform, inclusive of social media, any purported news or report, or purported statement of fact, knowing or having reasonable cause to suspect the same is: untrue or false; or may incite public fear, panic or ethnic hatred.
Regional or international military assistance may be requested
Out of an abundance of caution, the Governor General may authorize international or regional military or police forces to serve a peace officers to maintain order, and to ensure the safekeeping and distribution of supplies.
