In Tonga a State of Emergency has been announced, effective from 20 March 20.00 to 17 April, unless further renewed. Public gatherings are restricted. Nightclubs, bars and kava clubs shut down from 25 March. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are banned.

Effective 23 March, Tonga closes its borders, including international flights, cruise ships and yachts for 14 days. The restriction affects Fiji Airways, Air New Zealand, Virgin Australia, and Talofa Airways flights.

In Tonga, a nationwide lockdown has been declared from 29 March to 5 April. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. Night-time curfews will be in place from 20.00 to 06.00. Non-essential businesses will be closed and large gatherings will be suspended.

Trinidad and Tobago enforces fever scanners at the Piarco International airport, targeting flights from North America, the UK and Panama; starting January 22. People over 37.2 are questioned on their travel history, and if necessary quarantined and the country's infectious disease protocol will be enforced.

Trinidad and Tobago imposes a 14 day travel restriction for persons departing China. All people who have been to China over the past two weeks have to spend a 14 day incubation period in a non-risk country before entering T&T again.

Trinidad and Tobago expands travel restrictions to five additional countries (Italy, South Korea, Singapore, Japan, Iran), starting February 27. These measures were previously only applied to China. All travellers who have been to one of these regions are required to spend a 14 day incubation period in a non-risk region, before being allowed to enter the country again.
Trinidad and Tobago announces the establishment of a standing committee to deal with public health concerns and emerging infectious diseases, February 27.

Trinidad and Tobago enforces preparation in health facilities for an eventual (major) COVID-19 by adding hospital beds, and enabling whole hospitals to be operationalised for isolation capacity; announced February 27.

Trinidad and Tobago extend the travel restrictions to Spain, France and Germany. Individuals who have been to one of these regions have to remain in a non-risk region for a 14 day incubation period. After it has been assured that they have developed no symptoms, they are allowed to enter the country again; starting March 11.

PM of Trinidad and Tobago advices all schools, universities, and other places of learning to close down for at least one week from 14. March onwards, after reporting the first COVID-19 case two days previously.

Trinidad and Tobago restricts all entry for the next 14 days except for nationals, starting midnight March 17 and is supposed to last for 14 days. Exemptions can be granted in certain circumstances e.g. for CARPHA members and cargo ships.
Trinidad and Tobago encourages closure of private businesses and other non-essential businesses or to work from home, starting on March 15th.

Trinidad and Tobago discourages gatherings above 25 persons. All bars to remain closed and no in-house dining for the next 14 days and religious bodies asked to limit gatherings, starting March 16th. In case this discouragement is not sufficient, it threatens to draft legislations.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Trinidad and Tobago has announced to creation of Cabinet Sub Committees which will focus on education, finance and the social impact of COVID-19, March 16th.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: Trinidad and Tobago reduces the maximum allowed size in which people are allowed to gather from 25 to 10 people, from March 18th onwards.
Trinidad and Tobago decides to break parliament meetings for two weeks after March 20th.
Trinidad and Tobago closes international borders to all travelers, including Trinidad and Tobago nationals, and suspend all commercial flights into the country as of midnight on 22 March.

Trinidad and Tobago expands COVID-19 testing possibilities with the aim to test anyone who meets testing criteria. Two additional PCR machines are placed at the two facilities: one at EWMSC and the other at the Trinidad Public Health Laboratory by the end of the week to assist in expanding testing, starting March 23rd.

As of 23 March 2020, COVID-19 testing in Trinidad and Tobago has been expanded. The Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) will expand its testing to test anyone who meets any of the criteria for COVID-19 exposure.
As of 23 March, Trinidad and Tobago will suspend all permanent residence and citizenship interviews until further notice.

As of 23 March, in Trinidad and Tobago, citizens are being urged to not send their samples to private labs who claim to be doing rapid COVID-19 tests. These private labs are not equipped with PCR machines and therefore the results will be inaccurate.
As of 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago advises that all public transportation vehicles should operate with windows open and, where possible, limit their occupancy.

On 25 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Ministry of Health advises the population of a fake news post. It states that members of the public are not authorised to use the official letterhead of the Ministry of Health, in any form, and should refrain from doing so. The public is urged to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19.

Installation of fever screening by thermal cameras at the entrance to all airports and at sea and land entry points, intended for passengers at risk; from 22/01/2020.
Suspected cases will be followed up in the airport isolation unit for appropriate medical follow-up and sampling and diagnostic tests.
Travelers from risk areas who are non-pyretic at the time of screening, will be actively monitored by telephone for 14 days following the date of departure from the zones at risk, made aware of preventive measures and informed of the need to keep their home and to contact emergency medical services in case of any symptoms.

Strengthening of collaboration with the Office of Civil Aviation and Airports and airlines for the management of cases on board aircraft by the notification of any suspicious case and the identification of travelers from China and other areas at risk. This identification will be done by a dedicated questionnaire distributed during the flight and collected at the exit of the aircraft by border health control teams. The latter will proceed with the sorting at the exit of the aircraft.

Dissemination of communication messages at air, sea and land entry points, to all travelers through posters, leaflets and an electronic newsletter, aimed at educating travelers about preventive measures, signs and symptoms of the disease as well as the methods of their orientation and management in the event of the appearance of suggestive signs within 14 days of their return from the affected areas.

A free number to the Emergency medical services (190) is made available to the community for information and reporting of symptoms. Another toll-free number (80 10 19 19) is available to anyone wishing to inquire about the measures taken by Tunisia.

Development and dissemination of an information sheet at the air, sea and land entry points for all passengers entering Tunisia, in order to document precise information on the travel routes of each passenger and their contact details in Tunisia . This sheet is available in paper and electronic format.

Transfer of all flights from Italy to same terminal, in order to guarantee that there is no contact between travelers from this country and the rest of other countries. As a matter of course the Department of Health has provided all the requirements for health monitoring at this station to prevent COVID-19.

Intensification of media and awareness campaigns to raise awareness of the importance of quarantine adherence for travelers returning from at-risk areas, with the aim of ensuring the inclusion of all in the national plan to fight COVID -19. From March 4th.
Suspend the exchange of students and student delegations abroad, unless absolutely necessary, while taking the necessary health precautions from March 4th.
Suspend the exchange of students and student delegations abroad, unless absolutely necessary, while taking the necessary health precautions from March 4th.

Ministry of Health calls to carry out training actions for officials and executives of other ministries (education, higher education, transport, etc.) in order to contribute to the awareness-raising effort to combat COVID-19 in Tunisia from March 4th.

Suspension of all maritime crossings between Tunisia and Italy, limiting itself to a single crossing between Tunisia and France, Tunis / Marseille, instead of two. Suspension of flights to Italy, except to Rome and reduction of the number of flights from 14 to 3 only per week.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The original measures plan also included orders to maintain all flights to Malta at the rate of three weekly flights and maintaining the traffic of freight transport vessels, while respecting preventive measures, in particular the prohibition for all crews to leave the vessels when they moor in Tunisian ports.
Tunisia implements quarantine policies for passengers arriving from risk countries. Implemented 11/03/2020.

event_description: Ministry of Religious Affairs has prescribed several health measures to be observed within the mosque grounds. Invites imams to shorten their sermons and reduce the time between the call to prayer and prayer. Recommending citizens to do their ablutions at home before going to the mosque and to bring their own prayer mat.

The Ministry of Religious Affaires invites citizens to respect the health and regulatory measures issued by the Ministry of Health, as it invites imams to shorten their sermons and reduce the time between the call to prayer and prayer. The Ministry also calls on citizens to do their ablutions at home before going to the mosque and to bring their own prayer mat.

The Ministry of Religious Affaires invites citizens to respect the health and regulatory measures issued by the Ministry of Health, as it invites imams to shorten their sermons and reduce the time between the call to prayer and prayer. The Ministry also calls on citizens to do their ablutions at home before going to the mosque and to bring their own prayer mat. March 11th.
Immediate suspension of prayers in mosques, restricted opening hours for cafes (close cafes at 4pm every day), and ban of all cultural, sports and economic gatherings.
The government closed Tunisia's maritime borders, suspended all flights to and from Italy, in addition to reducing flights with Egypt, Germany, Britain and France.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The head of government, Elyes Fakhfakh announced Monday March 16th, that in four days from the announcement, there will be a total closure of the air and land borders, in prevention of the coronavirus. The last (air cargo-, transit-, official-, and Evacuation-) flights will until 20/04/2020 until 23:59.
National curfew applies throughout the Tunisian Territory between 6 pm and 6 am.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

event_description: The Ministry of Transport announces March 17th, the suspension of all flights to and from Tunisian airports. Exceptions made for air cargo flights, transit flights, official flights, and evacuation flights which are subject to prior authorization from the services of the Directorate General of Civil Aviation. All travellers arriving are required to comply with quarantine procedures.
Implementation of general confinement with limitation of movement unless absolutely necessary or for vital services. Implemented 22/03/2020, and later (31/03/2020) extended until 18/04/2020.

Tunisia has turned to robots to help enforce its nationwide lockdown measures as the country continues to battle the global Coronavirus pandemic. The P Guard robots, manufactured by local company ENOVA can be operated remotely and come equipped with infrared cameras, which cover the robots surroundings, as well as a thermal camera and a sound and light alarm system. It is unclear which public official spotted their potential for policing Tunisia’s lockdown, but their presence upon the streets of the capital have provided Tunis’ locked in residents with a sorely needed source of distraction.

In Turkey, as of March 16, all schools will be shut down until 30 March

In Turkey, the government has provided public awareness for all citizens in the form of promoting standard EN149 filtered masks against the virus, which have been initially recommended by the institution of medicine and medical equipment (İlaç ve Tıbbi Cihaz Kurumu), connected to the Ministry of Health.

Turkey has put a limit on all passengers taking public transport within and between cities. Public transport will from now on only accept passengers up to 50% of the entire carriage capacity of the vehicle.

Turkey is restricting all supermarkets in all cities and provinces to take in a maximum of one-tenth of their maximum customer capacity. However, supermarkets will still be able to operate between 9 am and 9 pm.
In Turkey, as of the date of 3 April residents under the age of 20, have been directed not to leave their homes.
Turkmenistan has "recommended the country’s citizens to refrain from traveling to China due to the coronavirus" on January 30.
"Turkmenistan suspends flights from February 6 to Bangkok and from February 7 to Beijing because of the coronavirus outbreak in China"
Turkmenistan announced that it had rolled out a public health campaign targeted at school children and other citizens, Feb. 7.

Turkmenistan has "put quarantine measures in place for foreign travelers arriving at airports as of Sunday, February 9." They may be put into hospitals if they show symptoms or have travel histories from places with the virus.
Turkmenistan announced that "Citizens arriving from abroad undergo medical check-up" on February 26.

In Turkmenistan, on March 13, "spoke in glowing terms about the protective properties of the plant known in Turkmen as yuzarlik (Peganum harmala)...in the days that followed his remarks, government buildings were fumigated with burning pans of yuzarlik."
Turkmenistan removed mentions of coronavirus from public health information pamphlets, as reported on March 17.
"From March 19 to April 30, 2020, Turkmenistan temporarily suspended all international flights."
In Turkmenistan "all previously planned mass events (exhibitions, fairs, sports events, matches, concerts, etc.) have been canceled or postponed" from March 19 to April 30.
Turkmenistan: "Movement into Ashgabat was suspended on March 19"

"Starting in March 20, in Turkmenistan, the movement of citizens between the provinces was restricted for an indefinite period...citizens will be allowed to travel only in urgent situations, on the basis of special permission, to participate in weddings and ceremonies, as well as for business trips. The state media did not inform residents of the new order."

event_description: In Turkmenistan citizens "are forbidden to talk about coronavirus," as reported on March 26.

On March 23, Turkmenistan has developed a temporary regulation on the movement of export, import and transit cargo through the territory of Turkmenistan. "Goods arriving by car through the customs checkpoints "Garabogaz" and "Farap" and following further on the territory of Turkmenistan will be transported by Turkmen cargo carriers." "The transfer of goods delivered in trailers or semi-trailers will be carried out in non-contact conditions at the state border in certain places.""Also, starting from March 24, all types of cargo that will arrive at the international seaport of Turkmenbashi should be loaded in trailers and semi-trailers to sea vessels and sent without accompanying individuals and without motor transport."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 23, people entering the Ashgabat, Turkmenistan are "required to have their temperature taken."
Turkmenistan extends school holidays in response to the coronavirus on March 30.
Turkmenistan established a coronavirus hotline on April 1.

entry_type: Correction to Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On February 3rd, 2020, the Government of Tuvalu announced "restrictions prohibiting entry to Tuvalu of anyone who has been in China within 30 days of arrival in Tuvalu. This restriction includes entry to seafarers from foreign vessels that have been in China or “a high-risk country” (understood to be countries where coronavirus is present) in the last 30 days."

Since February 3rd, travellers who have been to COVID-19 affected countries in the last 30 days need to obtain medical clearance three days before entering Tonga. Additionally, travellers must have remained in a country not affected by COVID-19 for at least five days prior to attempting entry.

On March 15th, 2020, the Government of Tuvalu announced that "restrictions prohibiting entry to Tuvalu of anyone who has been in China within 30 days of arrival in Tuvalu. This restriction includes entry to seafarers from foreign vessels that have been in China or “a high-risk country” (understood to be countries where coronavirus is present) in the last 30 days."
The Government of Tuvalu has declared a State of Emergency for Tuvalu effective on Friday, 20th March, 2020. The State of Emergency will last 14 days until further notice.
The Ugandan Ministry of Health shared measures on February 22, 2020, to be practiced by residents of Uganda so as to prevent spread of Covid-19.

As of March 7,2020 the Ministry of Health  imposed self- quarantine requirements for asymptomatic travelers and in- hospital isolation requirement for all symptomatic travelers arriving in Uganda after recent stays( within 14) days of arrival.
As of March 18,2020 the government of Uganda announced closure of all schools for 30 days effective Friday March 2020.

As of 18 March  2020,Uganda restricted travel to 17 virus hit countries including;
 Italy,France,South Korea,China,USA,United Kingdom,Netherlands,Switzerland,Sweden,Belgium,Germany,Spain,Norway,Austria,Malaysia,Pakistan and San Marino
As of 18 March 2020 the Uganda government banned all public gatherings, including worship,pubs,weddings,music shows,rallies and cultural meetings have been suspended for 32 days.

The government of Uganda announced the closure of Entebbe International Airport effective at 12:00 am March 23,2020,as well as the closure of all land borders.

No Individuals are allowed to enter or depart Uganda by air,land or water except for specific cargo vehicles which must follow strict ministry of health procedures
As of March 31,2020 the government of Uganda declared a dusk to dawn curfew; 7:00 pm to 6:30 am for 14 days

As of 31 March,2020 the government of Uganda declared a nationwide lockdown.

Private vehicles were banned from roads.

Closure of all shopping malls,Arcades,hardware shops,business selling non food items,saloons,lodges and garages for 14 days was declared mandatory.
Schools throughout Ukraine are closed through April 24.

UKRAINIAN GOVT INTRODUCES 'QUARANTINE' UNTIL APRIL 3 IN CONNECTION WITH COVID-19 - MP SIUMAR
Ukrainian Government introduces "Quarantine" until April 3 in connection with COVID-19 – MP Siumar

From 12 March until April 24, schooling will be stopped at nursery schools, general secondary schools, out-of- school educational institutions, colleges, universities, institutions of undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate learning.

All scheduled commercial international passenger services, including flights, trains and passenger buses to and from Ukraine are currently suspended.  Airlines, including Ukraine International Airlines, have conducted repatriation flights on a rolling basis, with unpredictable schedules. All foreigners without residence permits are barred from entering Ukraine.

Answers on "FAQ on COVID-19 – illness, triggered by the coronavirus" collected on an officiail website launched by the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine and the National Ministry of Health. Additionally, a channel on Telegram was launched to provide recent information on the national situation concerning COVID-19.

event_description: All educational institutions are closed until April 3.

On March 25, the Minister of Internal Affairs announced that Ukraine will suspend air travel from the evening of Friday, March 27.
    All scheduled commercial international passenger services, including flights, trains and passenger buses to and from Ukraine currently suspended.  Airlines, including Ukraine International Airlines, are opening repatriation flights on a rolling basis, with unpredictable schedules.
    As of March 16, all foreigners without residence permits were barred from entering Ukraine.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The Ukrainian government has extended the quarantine regime through April 24. All non-essential city services are closed except grocery stores, pharmacies, banks, and gas stations. In Kyiv, grocery stores and pharmacies are limited to one customer per 10 square meters and they may require patrons to wear masks. Grocery stores are currently well-supplied, but you should expect lines and delays.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: The government has banned gatherings larger than 10 people, including cultural, entertainment, sports, social, religious, advertising, and sporting events. Use of playgrounds and sports grounds is prohibited. Subways in Kyiv, Dnipro and Kharkiv are closed.  All other city transport, including buses and trams, may carry no more than 10 passengers at one time. City transport in Kyiv is limited to essential personnel with passes only.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: From 12 March until April 24, schooling will be stopped at nursery schools, general secondary schools, out-of- school educational institutions, colleges, universities, institutions of undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate learning.

Starting March 17, food supply, trade and entertaining enterprises, fitness clubs, and cultural establishments temporarily stop working. Cafes and restaurants are only open for take-out and delivery service only.
On 25 March, the Government introduced a 30-day emergency regime across Ukraine planned to end on 24 April 2020.
Starting April 6, it is mandatory to carry identification documents in public places.
Starting April 6, it is mandatory to carry identification documents in public places.
Ukraine will send humanitarian aid to Italy in a few days, namely a batch of alcohol disinfectants. A resuscitation helicopter is also being prepared for departure.
On January 23 2020, the UAE announced that all passengers arriving from China will have to undergo thermal screening at the airports.
On March 2nd 2020, the UAE evacuated Emirati citizens in the Islamic Republic of Iran.
link: UAE evacuates Emirati nationals from Iran

event_description: All UAE citizens evacuated from Iran on March 2nd are to be quarantined and monitored.

The UAE closed all schools and universities, starting on March 8, 2020, for a period of 4 weeks. During these 4 weeks, the schools will undergo a deep clean. The first 2 weeks are meant to be spring break, while the remaining two weeks will continue with online classes. This also restricts all trips, and extra-curricular activities.
On March 4, 2020, "The United Arab Emirates has coordinated the evacuation of Arab nationals from Wuhan City in China"

On March 4th, in order to care for the 215 individuals evacuated from Wuhan, the UAE set up a "purpose-built medical facility in the Emirates Humanitarian City which is equipped to provide preventive medical care and monitoring." Here the individuals' health will be monitored and they will remain in quarantine.

On the 5th of March 2020, the UAE urged citizens and residents to not travel abroad. They warned that upon return, individuals may have to face preventative measures such as temperature checks at airports and a 14-day home quarantine.

"The UAE has announced the suspension of all inbound and outbound flights with Italy, with the exception of flights to and from Rome, effective on 13 March. All passengers arriving from Rome International Airport are required to undergo thorough preventive medical tests at UAE airports to ensure that they are free from the virus."

"The UAE has announced the suspension of all inbound and outbound flights with Italy, with the exception of flights to and from Rome, effective on 13 March. All passengers arriving from Rome International Airport are required to undergo thorough preventive medical tests at UAE airports to ensure that they are free from the virus."
The UAE closed all areas of worships (mosques, churches, temples, etc) for a period of 4 weeks, starting on Monday, 16 March, 9pm.
The UAE suspended the entry of all valid residence visa holders, who are currently out of the country, from 19 March, for a renewable period of two weeks.
On March 18, " The UAE Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation issued a statement notifying Emirati nationals not to travel abroad, effective immediately, and until further notice"
UAE suspends issuance of all labour permits, including drivers and domestic workers, on March 19, 2020. However, the decision exempts intra-corporate transfer and EXPO 2020 permits.

On March 19, the UAE announced that were closing their borders to all  its borders to all travelers, including resident visa holders, to stop the spread of coronavirus. Emiratis were also banned from travel, except to return to the UAE. On March 20th, it was announced that GCC nationals would be let into the country and would have to undergo a medical test and place themselves in home quarantine. If they do not have a home they will be quarantined in designated places.

event_description: On March 22 2020, the UAE closed all leisure sites including "public and private beaches, parks, swimming pools, movie theaters, and sports halls and lounges", for a period of two weeks.

On March 21 2020, the UAE issued preventative measures for Food and Beverage outlets for a renewable period of 2 weeks, effective March 22nd. The measures state that F&B outlets will continue home delivery services during the closure. However, they are allowed to serve customers "provided only 20 percent of the seating capacity is used at any given time so that the necessary distance between people can be maintained. A physical distance of two meters between customers, in addition to other sanitation and public hygiene measures, must be ensured." The ruling exempts outdoor and self-order kiosks.
On March 23rd 2020, the UAE suspended all inbound, outbound and transit flights for a renewable period of 2 weeks.

On March 23rd 2020, the UAE announced the closure of all "commercial centres, and shopping malls along with fish, meat and vegetables markets. The decision excludes pharmacies, and food retail outlets, including cooperative societies, grocery stores, and supermarkets, along with fish, meat and vegetables markets dealing with wholesalers." The policy is effective on March 25th, for a renewable period of 2 weeks.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 23 2020, the UAE announced the closure of restaurants and limited their services to home deliveries only, effective March 25, for a renewable period of 2 weeks.

On march 23rd 2020, the UAE government urged the public to stay home "unless it's absolutely necessary to get essential supplies, such as food and medicine, or perform essential jobs". The statement also included limiting family cars to three individuals per vehicle and to not visit hospitals except for emergencies.

The UAE launched a 'National Disinfection Programme' to disinfect public facilities and public transport starting on March 26, 8pm and ending on March 29, 6am. The campaign also temporarily restricts movement of everyone except those working in 'vital sectors'.

The UAE "has decided that a maximum of 30 percent of the workforce of private entities is allowed to be physically present in office while others whose jobs don't necessitate their physical presence will be working remotely, effective Sunday 29th March" for a renewable period of two weeks.

On March 29, the UAE limited the workforce of private entities to a maximum of 30% of the entire workforce. Under these measures, private entities must ensure the following: 
"1.  provide screening devices at their entrances to take temperature and check symptoms of the virus among workforce on a daily basis twice
2. ensuring that the number of transported workers should not exceed 25 percent of vehicle seating capacity
3.report any worker with coronavirus symptoms or any suspected cases"

The UAE activated "Remote Work System for all ministries, authorities, and federal institutions, effective Sunday, March 29th, for a renewable period of two weeks." This includes having only 30% of the workforce present at a time and exempts vital sectors.

On 26th March 2020, the UAE announced that "Anyone violating preventive measures and instructions given by the government to contain the coronavirus, COVID-19, will receive a fine not less than AED500 and not more than AED50,000"

On March 28 2020, the UAE Attorney General imposed a "AED50,000 fine for violating mandatory hospitalisation by patients who directly refuse to receive or continue prescribed medicines despite being instructed. Concerned entities or specialists may contact relevant authorities to enforce the decision:

On March 28 2020, the UAE Attorney General imposed a series of fines regarding the failure of complying with precautionary measures:
- AED3,000 fine for refusing an order to dispose of any stuff, clothes, luggage or others proved to be contaminated or might be contaminated by any pathogen if they can’t be disinfected by established procedures.
- AED10,000 fine for failing to take precautionary measures for the crew of shelter ships.
- AED3,000 fine for violating the executive regulations of the Law on Communicable Diseases when burying or transporting a dead body infected with a communicable disease.

The UAE Attorney General imposed fines on the failure of closing public years:
- AED50,000 fine and administrative closure for failing to temporarily suspend an establishment. AED500 fine will be issued for a customer.
- AED50,000 fine and administrative closure for violating the closure instructions of educational institutions, cinemas, gyms, sports clubs, malls, outdoor markets, parks, cafés, shopping centres and restaurants and others or for receiving customers. A visitor to such establishments will be slapped with fine of AED500.

The UAE Attorney General imposed fines for not maintaing social distancing:
- AED1,000 fine for a motorist who exceeds the number of passengers in his car (more than three persons per car).
- AED10,000 fine for whoever invites or organises gatherings, meetings, private and public celebrations or being present in groups at public places or private farms. Participants will also be slapped a fine of AED5,000.
- AED3,000 fine for failing to take proper health measures regarding regulation of markets, roads, and other public places exempted from temporally closure.
- AED1,000 fine for unnecessarily visiting health facilities.

The UAE Attorney General imposed a "AED5,000 fine for the executive in charge of managing a company or a facility that violates the sterilisation measures of public or private means of transportation."

The UAE Attorney General imposed fines for leaving home:
- AED3,000 fine for individuals violating the curfew set out during the National Disinfection Programme by the Ministry of Health and Prevention and the Ministry of Interior. The fine excludes individuals who sought to obtain essential supplies, such as food and medicine, and individuals working within previously designated vital sectors.
-AED2,000 fine for any person leaving his home for unnecessary reasons except for performing vital jobs or buying essential necessities.

The UAE Attorney General imposed fines for not complying with health checks 
- AED50,000 fine for non-compliance with home quarantine instructions as per the home quarantine manuals, and quarantine at private facilities determined by competent authorities and refusing to take the test again as per health protocols or implementing these measures.
-  AED5,000 fine for refusing to subject to a medical test upon request.
- AED2,000 fine for violating precautionary measures issued by the Ministry of Health and Prevention by passengers coming to the UAE from countries infected by a communicable disease.

On March 27, 2020, the UAE issued a series of penalties  for violating measures taken to curb the spread of the virus.This came with a 1000 dhs penalty for not wearing masks indoors.It was clarified a day later on March 28, that this applied only to those that were sick or showing symptoms. 
 "The resolution stipulates 15 fines starting from AED1,000 for failing to wear medical masks indoors by only those individuals suffering from chronic diseases, and those showing cold and flu symptoms or failing to maintain social distancing."

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)

This allows for movement within the same emirate and also across emirates.

On January 20, Public Health England in the UK advises people travelling to Wuhan, China to "maintain good hand, respiratory and personal hygiene and should avoid visiting animal and bird markets or people who are ill with respiratory symptoms. Individuals should seek medical attention if they develop respiratory symptoms within 14 days of visiting Wuhan [...]".
A UK Foreign & Commonwealth Office spokesperson advised against non-essential travel to Wuhan, and advised UK nationals travelling to Wuhan to remain vigilant.

Public Health England has been directed to trace all individuals that have traveled back to the UK from Wuhan in the past 14 days. Anyone that has traveled back from Wuhan has been asked to self-isolate for 14 days.
British Ambassador to China, Dame Barbara Woodward, gives confirmation that assisted departure will be available for British nationals in Wuhan who wish to return to the UK.
UK government funds a campaign to help inform the public of safer practices in order to slow the spread of coronavirus and reduce the burden to the NHS
UK government pledges £20 million to fund the development of a vaccines for coronavirus and other infectious diseases
British Embassy in Beijing provides a Q&A regarding coronavirus for British nationals and their dependents currently in China
The coronavirus test developed by Public Health England is being rolled out to laboratories across the UK, allowing for around 1000 people to be tested per day for England alone.
UK aid will support WHO's Flash Appeal to stop the spread of coronavirus in developing countries with £5 million. This includes training of staff and spreading awareness of the disease.

'The Health Protection (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020' has been put together to impose restrictions on individuals at risk of spreading coronavirus in the UK. "The regulations apply to any individuals seeking to leave supported isolation before the current quarantine period of 14 days is complete"

"To relieve potential pressures on global supply chains, [UK] suppliers have been asked to carry out a risk assessment on the impact of coronavirus on their business. As an extra precaution, companies have also been asked to retain existing stockpiles of medical supplies, compiled as a contingency measure ahead of [the UK's] exit from the EU, where possible"
Foreign Secretary, "Dominic Raab has confirmed the evacuation flight back to the UK for British people on the Diamond Princess in Japan, following the coronavirus outbreak."
On March 3, The United Kingdom publishes its Coronavirus Action Plan.

The health and social care system across the UK created a 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) action plan. "This document sets out what the UK as a whole has done – and plans to do – to tackle the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, based on [their] experience dealing with other infectious diseases and [their] influenza pandemic preparedness work."

A public information campaign focusing on the importance of washing hands for 20 seconds has been started in the UK to slow down the spread of coronavirus. "The campaign will appear in the print media, radio, online and in public places, including billboards".
UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announces statutory sick pay, which is now available from the first day of sickness rather than the usual fourth day.

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) "will consider any evidence that companies may have broken competition or consumer protection law, for example by charging excessive prices or making misleading claims about the efficacy of protective equipment. And it will take direct enforcement action in appropriate cases."

"At 6.15pm on 5 March 2020, a statutory instrument was made into [UK] law that adds COVID-19 to the list of notifiable diseases and SARS-COV-2 to the list of notifiable causative agents."
"This change in law requires GPs to report all cases of COVID-19 to Public Health England."

Government outlines further plans to maximise the number of volunteers. "Volunteers – who already play a central role in helping the health and social care system function – will be given additional employment safeguards so they can leave their main jobs and temporarily volunteer in the event of a widespread pandemic."
On March 12, The United Kingdom announced that people with fever or 'continuous' cough should self-isolate.

On March 16, the UK announced that all non-essential contact with others and all unnecessary travel should be stopped, people should start working from home and avoid pubs, clubs, theatres and other such venues.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 16, The UK government asked the public to ensure "that if you or anyone in your household has one of those two symptoms [a high temperature or a new and continuous cough], then you should stay at home for fourteen days."
On March 16, the UK banned mass gatherings from March 17.

On March 17, UK Prime Minister sets up new ministerial structures to coordinate, prioritise and respond to the coronavirus pandemic across government, including one for Healthcare, General Public Sector, Economic and Business and International.
The United Kingdom advises against all non-essential travel from March 17 for a period of 30 days.
On March 18, the UK announces closing of schools, colleges and early years, except in the case of children of key workers and vulnerable children, from March 28.

Gatherings of two or more people, except members of households, are prohibited and will dispersed.
On March 23, The UK has banned public gatherings of more than 2 people except for members of households, the police can disperse such gatherings.
On March 23, the UK closes public premises such as libraries, playgrounds and outdoor gyms, and places of worship.
On March 23, the UK stops all social events including weddings, baptisms and other ceremonies, but excluding funerals.

All Ports of entry (airports and border crossings) in Tanzania  are conducting screening and travelers with a fever are diverted to secondary for further examination
As from 16 March 2020 the government of Tanzania shut down schools for 30 days.

All universities and colleges across Tanzania to be closed

All BRT buses will be required to carry passengers according to their operating license (nobody is allowed to be standing in DalaDalas etc.)

All travelers whether foreigners or returning residents arriving from COVID-19 most affected countries will be subjected to mandatory isolation for 14 days at their own cost at designated facilities identified by the Government.
Passengers should fill in Health Surveillance Form in the plane, or any other transport means and submit them to Port Health Authorities upon arrival.
All travelers will be subjected to an intensive screening and where necessary COVID-19 rapid testing.
People residing in Tanzania are advised to avoid non-essential travels to COVID-19 affected countries

In Tanzania all travellers will be subjected to an intensive screening and where necessary COVID-19 rapid testing.

In Tanzania after 14 days quarantine, passengers who have not developed symptoms of COVID-19 may leave the facilities and will be required to register personal information for future possible tracking purpose after March 23.

In Tanzania Turkey helps Tanzania fight coronavirus, drill water wells, rescue albinos.

US Health and Human Services Secretary declares public health emergency retrospectively for January 27, 2020 on Friday, January 31, 2020.
On January 31 the United States President signed a proclamation barring entry to the United States of most foreign nationals who traveled to China within the past 14 days.
US government officials issue level 4 travel advisory, urging residents not to travel to China on the 2nd of February 2020 without an indicated end.

On Feb 15, 2020 the US announce that 17.8 tons of personal protection equipment and medical supplies were delivered, and more than 800 people were evacuated from Wuhan, China, amidst the Novel Coronavirus outbreak.
The US CDC issues guidance for pregnant women and information on breastfeeding related to COVID-19.
On Feb 27, 2020 the White House (US) announces that Debbie Birx will serve as the White House Coronavirus Response Coordinator.
On 02-28-20 the CDC issues criteria to Guide Evaluation and Testing of Patients Under Investigation (PUI) for COVID-19

On February 29, President Trump signed a proclamation that expanded restrictions to include all aliens who were physically present within the Islamic Republic of Iran during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States.
Interim Guidance for Healthcare Facilities: Preparing for Community Transmission of COVID-19 in the United States, issued on 03-02-2020.

The U.S. Government announced on March 2, a commitment of $37 million in financing from the Emergency Reserve Fund for Contagious Infectious Diseases at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) for 25 countries affected by novel coronavirus COVID-19 or at high risk of its spread.

entry_type: Update on Existing Entry (type in Record ID in text box)
event_description: On March 08, 2020 an US CDC Health Alert Network (HAN) Update highlights guidance and recommendations for evaluating and identifying patients who should be tested for COVID-19. It supersedes the guidance and recommendations provided in CDC’s HAN 428 distributed on February 28, 2020. The update is targeted at health care workers to instruct them on how to determine whether a patient shows or does not show symptoms of COVID-19 and should or should not be tested.

On March 11, President Trump signed a proclamation that restricts travel to the United States from foreign nationals who have recently been in certain European countries.  This does not apply to U.S. citizens or legal permanent residents.
United States decides 03-11-2020 to host the upcoming G7 ministerial virtually by video teleconference instead of gathering in Pittsburgh on March 24-25.

On March 11, 2020 the President of the United States announces an economic assistance package to help support businesses and workers who have been harmed by this outbreak.
This action will provide more than $200 billion of additional liquidity to the economy.

Temporary Pause of International Exchange Programs Due to Covid-19 announced by the White House March 12, 2020.

The Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs (ECA) will temporarily pause all ECA-funded programs that involve travel to and from countries with heightened U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Alert Level 2 (Practice Enhanced Precautions) and Warning Level 3 (Avoid Nonessential Travel) or heightened State Department COVID-19 related Travel Advisory Levels 3 (Reconsider Travel) and 4 (Do Not Travel).
President of the US declares a state of national emergency, March 13 2020.

US, march 12 2020. Pursuant to section 319 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 247d).  Our response must include heightened coordination among Federal, State, local, and tribal agencies, and we must offer States the flexibility they need to care for their citizens.  In accordance with this principle, the Food and Drug Administration, in coordination with the State of New York, allowed the State flexibility in expediting State-approved COVID-19 testing.

Should additional States request flexibility to authorize laboratories within the State to develop and perform tests used to detect COVID-19, the Secretary shall take appropriate action, consistent with law, to facilitate the request.
MOBILIZING ALL FEDERAL RESOURCES: US President Donald J. Trump is leveraging the full power of the Federal Government to protect the health and safety of the American people (March 13, 2020).

On March 17,2020 the US Ministry of Health Agency CDC issued a warning (Warning - Level 3, Avoid Nonessential Travel—Widespread Ongoing Transmission) on travel with cruiseships.

US President Trump issues Executive Order on Prioritizing and Allocating Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of Covid-19. 

To ensure that our healthcare system is able to surge capacity and capability to respond to the spread of COVID-19, it is critical that all health and medical resources needed to respond to the spread of COVID-19 are properly distributed to the Nation’s healthcare system and others that need them most at this time.

Accordingly, I find that health and medical resources needed to respond to the spread of COVID-19, including personal protective equipment and ventilators, meet the criteria specified in section 101(b) of the Act (50 U.S.C. 4511(b)).  Under the delegation of authority provided in this order, the Secretary of Health and Human Services may identify additional specific health and medical resources that meet the criteria of section 101(b).

event_description: US President Donald J. Trump today announced on March 18, 2020 a major partnership with the Ad Council, major media networks, and digital platforms to effectively communicate accurate and timely information directly to the American people. This partnership is another important component of the all-of-America response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), and will benefit high-risk populations and the general public with public service announcements (PSAs) around social distancing, personal hygiene, and mental health.

event_description:
On March 18, 2020, the US President announced more groundbreaking steps to slow the spread of the virus and help every American community brave the storm:

The Defense Department will massively expand medical resources, making 5 million respirator masks and 2,000 ventilators available for use
FEMA is now activated in every region of the country and at the highest level
The Department of Housing & Urban Development will be suspending foreclosures and evictions until the end of April
Health & Human Services will also suspend foreclosures and evictions
Navy hospital ships are being deployed to impacted areas
America and Canada will halt all non-essential travel across their border

On March 18, 2020 release of $62 million from the Emergency Reserve Fund for Contagious Infectious-Disease Outbreaks (ERF) at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to address the pandemic of COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus now called SARS-CoV-2. This funding fulfills the pledge of up to $100 million for international efforts to combat COVID-19 announced by the U.S. Department of State on February 7, 2020.

On March 20, 2020 The United States announced to have reached mutual agreements with Canada and Mexico to restrict non-essential travel across our northern and southern borders.
The United States will expeditiously return aliens who cross between ports of entry or are otherwise not allowed to enter the country, as the facilities in which these aliens would normally be held cannot support quarantine for the time needed to assess potential cases.
These aliens are processed in stations designed for short-term processing, where distancing is not a viable option, creating a serious danger of an outbreak.

US announces that Tax Day will be moved from April 15 to July 15. No interest or penalties will be charged for filing during this extended window, but any American expecting refunds or credits may claim now to get their money sooner.
To minimize impact on our nation’s students, the Department of Education is temporarily waiving all interest on federally held student loans. Secretary Betsy DeVos has also directed federal lenders to allow borrowers to suspend their student loan payments without penalty for at least the next 60 days.
March 22, 2020 the US Federal Government issues a Memorandum on Providing Federal Support for Governors’ Use of the National Guard to Respond to COVID-19.

The White House announced on March 23, 2020 the launch of the COVID-19 High Performance Computing Consortium to provide COVID-19 researchers worldwide with access to the world’s most powerful high performance computing resources that can significantly advance the pace of scientific discovery in the fight to stop the virus.

March 23, 2020 the US government issues an Executive Order on Preventing Hoarding of Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of COVID-19.
The president writes "Accordingly, I am delegating to the Secretary my authority under section 102 of the Act (50 U.S.C. 4512) to prevent hoarding of health and medical resources necessary to respond to the spread of COVID-19 within the United States. I am also delegating to the Secretary my authority under the Act to implement any restrictions on hoarding, including my authority under section 705 of the Act (50 U.S.C. 4555) to gather information, such as information about how supplies of such resources are distributed throughout the Nation.

US President Trump announces to provide 16$ billion for the purchase of personal protective equipment."And we also have $16 billion in funding for the purchase of personal protective equipment — you know about that — such as masks and respirators through the Strategic National Stockpile."

Uruguay establishes working subgroups within various institutions, including e.g.: National Defense, WHO, Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (Interamerican development bank), Facultad de Ciencias Instituto Pasteur (Science Faculty of Pasteur Institute), National Emergency Board, directors of the Health ministry on March 3rd.

Uruguay orders quarantine for people with COVID-19, their direct contact persons and anyone with fever and respiratory symptoms who stayed in high risk areas. As well as anyone who enters Uruguay coming from 
Spain, Italy, France, Germany, China, South Korea, Japan, Singapore or Iran.
Uruguay launches a public awareness campaign, amongst other things by distributing flyers on March 13.

Uzbekistan is "giving quality medical and sanitary examinations to travellers going through sanitary and quarantine checkpoints. Those sick with pneumonia and other acute respiratory diseases are being isolated and sent to hospital," in particular for Chinese citizens, said a message on Jan. 21.
Uzbekistan "suspended scheduled flights to and from China on February 1"
Uzbekistan is placing evacuated citizens from China in quarantine for 14 days.

Uzbekistan announced "the suspension of flights operations to and from South Korea, Afghanistan, Iran, and Italy effective immediately due to concerns about the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. It remains unclear how long the suspension will be effective for."
Uzbekistan "has suspended the export of medical facemasks, protective gear, sanitation agents, and some medicines in favor of its domestic market" as of March 16.

Vanuatu introduced additional border protection for those who have been in or transited through any part of China, Taiwan, Macau or Hong Kong in the past 14 days. Denial of entry. Effective from 01/31/20202.

Except:
Passengers who have traveled to or been in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao, or Taiwan as of December 31, and spent the 14 days prior to their arrival in Vanuatu in another country, will be required to provide a medical certification issued by a doctor stating that they do not have respiratory illnesses.

Any traveler showing symptoms of respiratory illness (fever, runny nose, flu-like condition, headache, chest pain, or breathing difficulties) must provide a medical certificate indicating a negative result of the 2019-nCoV coronavirus test.

In Zambia, "Isolation facilities to safely manage cases and limit spread of disease have been designated at district level across the country."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "Laboratory testing capacity for COVID-19 has been established at the University Teaching Hospital Virology Laboratory and at the School of Vetinary Medicine at the University of Zambia."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "Infection prevention and control measures are being strengthened, with procurement of disinfectants and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) including gloves, face masks, aprons and hand hygiene supplies."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "Community engagement through radio, TV, and social media platforms, and distribution of Information Education and
Communication (IEC) materials is ongoing. Parliamentarians have also been engaged to facilitate and promote community awareness in their constituencies"

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "A Call Centre has been established for the public to report concerns and also receive information on the disease. Dedicated Call Centre numbers are 909 (toll-free), 0953898941, 0964638726 and 0974493553."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "Specialized training for key healthcare workers and surge staff including immigration, customs, defense, security and point of entry personnel is being rolled out countrywide. Guidelines for
various aspects of preparedness and response have been developed and distributed to health facilities, including the private sector."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020: "The Government of the Republic of Zambia has established an Emergency Fund to provide resources for COVID-19
preparedness, surveillance and response."
14 March 2020: With immediate effect, the Government of The Republic of Zambia is enforcing "Mandatory reporting of all individuals suspected to have COVID-19 to health officials."

event_description: 14 March 2020: Zambia enforces "Mandatory isolation of all suspected and confirmed cases of COVID-19."
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

event_description:
14 March 2020: Zambia is enforcing "A mandatory requirement for the provision of adequate and accessible facilities for hand hygiene at all public places including shopping malls, markets and other trading places, restaurants, bars, bus stations, places of worship, schools, offices, and other congregate settings. Hand hygiene facilities should include soap
and running water, or alcohol-based hand sanitizers."

In Zambia, 14 March 2020, the Ministry of Health issued a statement: "Social distancing of at least one meter is encouraged when an individual is showing respiratory symptoms such as cough and/or sneezing. Individuals showing such symptoms are urged to stay at home and avoid interacting with the public."

On 17 March 2020, in Zambia, "A restriction has been imposed on all foreign travel, with the public being advised to reschedule all avoidable travel. Hygiene practices to promote infection prevention in all passenger vehicles, airplanes, marine transport, and other conveyances, and points of entry such as airports, harbors, railway stations, and ground crossings is emphasized."
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

event_description:
On 17 March 2020, the Minister of Health in Zambia announced; "We are restricting public mass gathering and social distancing mandated to prevent infections. Organizations within-country have been requested to
reschedule public events or use technology to advance their agenda.
We are engaging the Ministries of Education and Higher Education to
consider bringing forward closing dates."
In Zambia, as of 23rd March 2020, "All learning institutions to be closed for 30 days."

On 23 March 2020, Ministry of Health and Child Care release a statement on CORONAVIRUS (COVID-19) update. According to that statement, President Cde. E.D Mnangagwa announced additional measures which take immediate effect. Those measures include - 1. Border control both inbound and outbound except for the movement of cargo. The government will close all borders to human traffic, excluding returning residents. 2. Ban on entertainment and recreational activities stating that government put a blanket ban. 3. All public gatherings should not exceed 50 persons. (religious fellowship, weddings, conferences, workshops and funerals. and 4. restriction on hospital visits; hospital visits have been reduced to one visit perday, invovling one relative per patient.

Zimbabwe announced additional measures to minimize spread of COVID-19. Government decided to ban all non-essential travel and traffic both inbound and outbound, except for movement of cargo. The government will close all borders to human traffic, excluding returning residents.

Zimbabwe will impose a nationwide lockdown for 21 days from Monday to help curb the spread of the coronavirus, and security forces may be deployed to enforce it, President Emmerson Mnangagwa said on Friday by Independent Online Digital media.
